GREEN_EFA proposes expanding awareness campaigns to explicitly counter Golden Dawn-style xenophobia by naming specific high-risk regions in Article 14(b) while maintaining full support for the anti-discrimination framework.  
GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the call to replace the Dublin Regulation's border-state bias with GDP/population criteria, matching their decade-long advocacy for systemic responsibility shifts.  
GREEN_EFA approves the root-cause approach to migration but suggests enhancing third-country cooperation clauses to include climate displacement protections under AMF funding priorities.

SD totally approves the issue's emphasis on establishing a CEAS with integrated responsibility-sharing, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to EU asylum system reforms that prioritize human rights and equitable burden distribution.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for financial solidarity through AMF and EASO tools, recognizing this as critical to advancing SD's long-standing goal of protecting frontline states from disproportionate pressures.  
SD totally approves the critique of the Dublin Regulation's structural inequities, viewing its proposed replacement with GDP-based relocation as essential to realizing SD's vision of a genuinely collective asylum approach.  
SD perfectly supports the issue's focus on safeguarding non-refoulement and asylum seekers' rights, reflecting SD's unwavering adherence to international protection standards enshrined in the Geneva Convention.  
SD totally approves leveraging AMF flexibility for crisis response, seeing this as effectively advancing SD's manifesto pledge to operationalize solidarity through rapid funding access and capacity-building.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for enhanced intra-EU solidarity and responsibility-sharing in asylum policies, emphasizing the establishment of a fair and efficient Common European Asylum System (CEAS) aligned with international and EU law, including the Geneva Convention, ECHR, and EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. It highlighted disparities in asylum application distribution, noting that in 2011, ten Member States handled over 90% of applications, while only 4,125 refugees were resettled across ten states, and 227 beneficiaries were relocated from Malta. The resolution called for financial and administrative support to Member States facing disproportionate pressures, particularly those at EU entry points, through tools like the Asylum and Migration Fund (AMF) and the European Asylum Support Office (EASO), which should prioritize emergency assistance, capacity-building, and coordination of joint processing and relocation schemes. It criticized the Dublin Regulation for placing undue burdens on border states and urged reforms, including a potential EU distribution key for relocation based on GDP, population, and integration capacity. The Parliament stressed the importance of data collection, compliance with non-refoulement, and safeguarding asylum seekers' rights, while addressing xenophobia through awareness campaigns. It advocated for flexible funding under the AMF, including up to 90% EU co-financing for critical projects, and urged cooperation with third countries to address root causes of migration. The resolution also called for evaluating the Temporary Protection Directive’s activation criteria and improving mutual trust via consistent asylum standards and early warning mechanisms to prevent systemic failures.

title: Establishment of 'Eurodac' for the comparison of fingerprints: REPORT on the amended proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the establishment of 'EURODAC' for the comparison of fingerprints for the effective application of Regulation (EU) No […/…] (establishing the criteria and mechanisms for determining the Member State responsible for examining an application for international protection lodged in one of the Member States by a third-country national or a stateless person) and to request comparisons with EURODAC data by Member States' law enforcement authorities and Europol for law enforcement purposes and amending Regulation (EU) No 1077/2011 establishing a European Agency for the operational management of large-scale IT systems in the area of freedom, security and justice (recast)
background: Persistent disparities in EU asylum procedures and responsibility-sharing mechanisms, coupled with migration pressures on frontline states, highlighted inefficiencies in existing fingerprint data systems for asylum applications. The Parliament will discuss establishing updated EURODAC regulations to enhance asylum criteria application and enable controlled law enforcement access for serious crime investigations.

stances.stance:
EPP fully sanctions the EURODAC reforms as a critical advancement in harmonizing asylum procedures, perfectly aligning with its commitment to secure borders and combat migratory abuse through enhanced biometric data governance.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on minimum reception standards, particularly applauding provisions for unaccompanied minors and vulnerable groups as a testament to Europe’s human dignity principles.  
EPP proposes strengthening future solidarity mechanisms to complement Dublin reforms, ensuring peripheral states receive proportional support while maintaining responsibility-sharing frameworks.  
EPP highlights EURODAC’s law enforcement access as a model for balancing asylum integrity with cross-border crime prevention, effectively advancing its security agenda.  
EPP urges swift implementation of accelerated asylum procedures to deter economic migrants, framing this as essential to preserving public trust in protection systems.

GREEN_EFA rejects the EURODAC expansion as it fully doubts with their principle of protecting asylum seekers' dignity by equating them with criminals through mandatory fingerprinting in security databases.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's failure to prohibit detention of minors and vulnerable groups, directly contradicting their demands for trauma-sensitive asylum procedures.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the proposal's tolerance of divergent national asylum standards, which perpetuates a "lottery system" inconsistent with their vision of uniform EU-wide human rights protections.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the issue's acceptance of prolonged asylum processing delays (up to 21 months) as a violation of their core commitment to swift, humane refugee status determinations.  
GREEN_EFA firmly disapproves linking migration control to law enforcement access to EURODAC, arguing this securitization framework betrays Europe's obligations under refugee conventions.

ALDE strongly endorses the establishment of Eurodac as a critical step toward a coherent EU asylum system, aligning with their commitment to solidarity and humane treatment of asylum seekers. They highlight the importance of safeguarding vulnerable groups like unaccompanied minors and victims of torture, urging strict adherence to the European Court of Justice's rulings on their protection.  

ALDE applauds the negotiated three-year limit on law enforcement access to Eurodac data, viewing this as a crucial safeguard that balances security needs with individual rights. They emphasize that this restriction reflects their principled stance against undue surveillance of those granted international protection.  

ALDE welcomes provisions enabling asylum seekers' access to labor markets after nine months, recognizing this as vital for integration and self-sufficiency. They urge member states to implement this measure without bureaucratic delays, aligning with ALDE's economic inclusion priorities.  

While endorsing the package, ALDE proposes future reforms to replace the Dublin system with a fairer distribution mechanism, citing current inconsistencies in family reunification and member state responsibilities. They stress that maintaining the status quo contradicts EU values of shared burden-bearing.  

ALDE emphasizes that the issue's transparency requirements and interinstitutional coordination mechanisms effectively advance their long-standing goals of accountable EU governance. They call for rigorous monitoring of implementation to ensure uniform standards across all member states.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the expansion of EURODAC access to law enforcement authorities as a dangerous perversion of its original asylum purpose.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's failure to prohibit detention of asylum seekers in regular prisons and unaccompanied minors, contradicting core human rights principles.  
GUE_NGL condemns the perpetuation of the Dublin Regulation's "first entry" logic that disproportionately burdens border states and denies asylum seekers' dignity.  
GUE_NGL denounces accelerated border procedures and "safe third country" transfers as systemic violations of due process in international protection claims.  
GUE_NGL declares the criminalization of asylum seekers through police database access irreconcilable with their status as rights-holders under international law.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal (COM(2012)0254), emphasizing that the text constituted a straightforward codification of existing legal provisions without substantive amendments beyond those explicitly identified. It adopted its first-reading stance based on the Consultative Working Party’s assessment, which confirmed the proposal’s technical nature and lack of material changes to earlier acts. The resolution urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces the proposal, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural adherence. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional coordination under relevant Treaty articles (TFEU 294(2), 78(2)(e), 87(2)(a), and 88(2)(a)) and the 2001 Interinstitutional Agreement on recasting legal acts.

title: Establishment of an evaluation mechanism to verify application of the Schengen acquis: REPORT on the draft Council regulation on the establishment of an evaluation mechanism to verify the application of the Schengen acquis
background: The Schengen Area’s existing intergovernmental evaluation framework faced criticism for inconsistent application of border control rules and insufficient oversight, prompting calls for a standardized EU-level mechanism to ensure compliance. The Parliament will discuss establishing a revised evaluation system to strengthen governance of the Schengen acquis.

stances.stance:
EPP completely advocates the enhanced Schengen evaluation mechanism as a vital reinforcement of Europe's border security architecture  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on Commission-led evaluations to ensure objective scrutiny of member states' border management practices  
EPP applauds the integration of Frontex expertise into monitoring processes, fulfilling their manifesto commitment to operationalize EU border protection tools  
EPP emphasizes future enhancement opportunities through increased parliamentary oversight of Schengen governance decisions   
EPP categorically rejects nationalist narratives about Schengen's security impacts while endorsing temporary border measures only under strict Commission supervision

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's exclusion of Parliament from Schengen governance, fundamentally doubting with their principle of supranational democratic oversight.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the vagueness of "defects in external border control" as grounds for internal border closures, deeming this a threat to free movement rights.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's tolerance of racial profiling through practices like targeting Eastern European license plates, which contradicts anti-discrimination commitments.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the prioritization of national discretion over EU-level evaluation, inconsistent with their vision of integrated Schengen management.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the framing of migration as a security threat requiring border closures, a stance that undermines solidarity and human rights frameworks.

ALDE strongly accepts the evaluation mechanism's establishment, aligning perfectly with their commitment to robust Schengen governance and integrated border management.  
ALDE approves the issue’s adherence to interinstitutional procedural commitments, effectively advancing their priority of coherent EU policy implementation.  
ALDE proposes enhancing Article 4’s transparency by mandating quarterly progress reports to Parliament, ensuring oversight without undermining the evaluation framework.  
ALDE commends the cross-institutional collaboration reflected in the joint statement, reinforcing their advocacy for cooperative justice and home affairs governance.  
ALDE endorses the Committee on Civil Liberties’ structured methodology, noting its alignment with their manifesto goals for systematic Schengen area integrity checks.

GUE_NGL rejects the reintroduction of border controls justified by migration flows as a violation of free movement and a scapegoating of migrants, absolutely rejecting with their commitment to free movement and migrant rights.  
GUE_NGL opposes the two-year extension of border controls under the "emergency clause," which undermines Schengen’s core principle of abolishing internal borders and disproportionately targets vulnerable populations.  
GUE_NGL condemns the exclusion of parliamentary oversight in the evaluation mechanism, highlighting its contradiction with democratic accountability and institutional balance in EU governance.  
GUE_NGL argues the issue legitimizes political misuse of Schengen by member states, enabling border controls as a bargaining tool rather than safeguarding free movement as a fundamental right.  
GUE_NGL acknowledges the evaluation mechanism’s limited transparency but rejects the overall framework for institutionalizing border control reinstatement without addressing root causes of migration challenges.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the Council draft (10273/2013) concerning measures under Article 70 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, endorsing the joint statement by Parliament, the Council, and the Commission annexed to the resolution. The resolution emphasized the adoption of the act as transmitted by the Council, following the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report (A7-0215/2013), and instructed its President to formally communicate Parliament’s position to the Council and the Commission, ensuring alignment with the agreed framework and procedural commitments outlined in the interinstitutional agreement.

title: European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (FRONTEX): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004 establishing a European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (FRONTEX)
background: Persistent migratory pressures along EU external borders, particularly in Southern Europe and the Mediterranean, and operational challenges faced by FRONTEX since its 2004 establishment prompted calls to strengthen border management. The Parliament will discuss amending the agency’s mandate to enhance operational capacity and address human rights obligations in border operations.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the binding solidarity mechanism in the Frontex reform, aligning perfectly with their commitment to equitable burden-sharing among Member States.  
EPP approves the creation of permanent border guard teams and acquisition of autonomous operational resources as critical for rapid crisis response capabilities.  
EPP emphasizes the issue's advancement of integrated border management through mandatory coordination with Europol and Eurojust, enhancing cross-border crime prevention.  
EPP endorses the reinforced fundamental rights safeguards including consultative forums and asylum access protocols, consistent with their human dignity priorities.  
EPP suggests enhancing third-country cooperation frameworks in future reviews to address migratory pressures at their origin while maintaining current provisions.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to establish independent human rights monitoring mechanisms for FRONTEX operations  
GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the acceptance of "severe" human rights violations as operational thresholds under Article 6(3)  
This completely disputes with GREEN_EFA's demand for absolute non-refoulement guarantees in maritime interdiction protocols  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of democratic accountability by maintaining restricted parliamentary access to operational reports  
GREEN_EFA condemns the continued prioritization of border militarization over asylum access rights in Articles 8-11 implementation guidelines

ECR strongly agrees empowering FRONTEX with enhanced operational tools to intercept irregular migrants, aligning with their border security priorities under Article 77 TFEU.  
ECR approves the issue's emphasis on subsidiarity through Schengen reforms enabling national governments to address exceptional migratory pressures.  
ECR endorses cross-border cooperation mechanisms to resolve migratory challenges without intra-EU confrontation, reflecting their multilateral governance principles.  
ECR proposes augmenting FRONTEX's budget allocation for rapid deployment capabilities while maintaining the issue's core objectives.  
ECR commends the alignment with judicial cooperation frameworks as critical for lawful border operations under the Treaties.

GUE_NGL rejects the Frontex mandate expansion as fundamentally incompatible with human rights protections, citing documented migrant deaths and unlawful pushbacks in Mediterranean operations  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's failure to prohibit violence in border operations, directly contradicting their principle that "people cannot be illegal" and requiring non-militarized migration responses  
This fully disapproves with GUE_NGL's position that border agencies inherently violate dignity by categorizing migrants, instead demanding continental asylum system reforms per Article 78 TFEU  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as binding accountability mechanisms for Frontex officers' actions and meaningful third-country refugee resettlement commitments  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's authorization of mass charter deportations without data protection guarantees, exacerbating risks of refoulement to conflict zones like Libya

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the legislative proposal on EU procedures for international protection and border management (COM(2010)0061), emphasizing compliance with the Treaties and subsidiarity principles. It adopted its first-reading position, approving an annexed statement outlining its stance, and called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial amendments or replacements were planned. The resolution highlighted the Polish Senate’s reasoned objection that the proposal breached subsidiarity, while noting the European Economic and Social Committee’s supportive opinion from 15 July 2010. It instructed the Parliament’s President to forward the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reflecting commitments under Article 294 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU and procedural obligations under Rule 55 of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure. The resolution aimed to ensure alignment with legal bases in Articles 74 and 77(1)(b)-(c) TFEU, focusing on judicial cooperation and border controls.

title: European Arrest Warrant: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on the review of the European Arrest Warrant
background: The European Arrest Warrant, established in 2002 to streamline cross-border judicial cooperation, faced operational challenges including divergent national interpretations, proportionality concerns in minor offenses, and debates over fundamental rights protections amid evolving EU criminal justice integration. The Parliament will discuss balancing efficient law enforcement with procedural safeguards and mutual trust mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the European Arrest Warrant framework as fundamentally incompatible with national sovereignty and traditional legal safeguards like habeas corpus and trial by jury.  
EFD opposes the issue's proportionality assessments, arguing they fail to address systemic injustices where individuals are extradited without prima facie evidence or case-ready trials.  
The proposal totally challenges with EFD's position that mutual recognition mechanisms erode Britain's independent justice system in service of EU federalization goals.  
EFD condemns the UK government's decision to opt into the EAW as a betrayal, emphasizing that existing international cooperation tools render EU harmonization unnecessary and dangerous.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects such as prolonged pre-trial detention under continental systems, which the EAW exacerbates by bypassing evidentiary standards upheld in British courts.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates mandating proportionality assessments for EAW issuance, aligning with their commitment to preventing judicial overreach in cross-border cases.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing the issue by explicitly requiring refusal of EAWs when prison conditions breach human dignity, citing systemic failures in certain Member States.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the prioritization of alternatives to detention, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for minimizing coercive measures in judicial cooperation.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of implementing human rights safeguards within the one-year timeline to halt preventable miscarriages of justice under the current EAW framework.  
GREEN_EFA endorses standardized judicial training and case-law databases as critical steps toward reconciling mutual recognition with fundamental rights protections.

SD strongly agrees the mandatory proportionality assessments for EAW issuance, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to preventing disproportionate extradition for minor offenses like drug possession cases.  
SD firmly upholds establishing human rights refusal grounds, effectively advancing SD's priority of upholding EU Charter and ECHR obligations in cross-border judicial cooperation.  
SD proposes amending Article 6 to explicitly require EU-wide minimum defense standards during EAW proceedings, including guaranteed translation rights and legal aid access.  
SD approves the linkage between detention reforms and mutual trust, emphasizing this resolves systemic issues like prolonged pre-trial detention that undermine judicial cooperation.  
SD strongly agrees centralized case-law databases and training programs, recognizing these as critical enhancements to legal certainty and consistent EAW application across Member States.

ECR conditionally approves the EAW's role in combating cross-border terrorism but requests binding proportionality thresholds to prevent misuse for minor offenses, citing cases like prolonged detentions without trial.  
ECR urges amendments to Article 6 requiring judicial authorities to certify trial readiness before EAW issuance, addressing concerns about "languishing in jail" raised by Kirkhope.  
ECR highlights Croatia's Perković-Mustač case as evidence for mandatory refusal grounds when dual criminality principles are unevenly applied, demanding stricter oversight of national courts.  
ECR supports cross-border police cooperation but insists the issue must explicitly exclude politically motivated prosecutions, aligning with Bielan's warnings about "selective judicial actions."  
ECR rejects blanket mutual recognition without harmonized pre-trial detention standards, proposing EU-wide minimum criteria for prison conditions to address Tomašić's concerns over legal arbitrariness.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the implementation and operation of the European Arrest Warrant (EAW) framework, emphasizing the need to balance efficiency with fundamental rights safeguards. It highlighted the EAW’s role in accelerating cross-border judicial cooperation but identified gaps, including inconsistent application, lack of proportionality checks, and insufficient protection of suspects’ rights. The resolution called for legislative reforms, urging the Commission to propose measures within a year to address systemic issues, such as standardizing the definition of "judicial authority," mandating proportionality assessments for EAW issuance (considering offense severity, trial readiness, and human rights impacts), and establishing consultation procedures between Member States to resolve execution concerns. It stressed the necessity of mandatory refusal grounds for EAWs incompatible with human rights obligations under the EU Charter and ECHR, alongside enhanced legal remedies for individuals. The Parliament urged Member States to prioritize alternative measures to detention, improve prison conditions in line with human dignity, and ensure compensation for miscarriages of justice. It emphasized data collection on EAW use, withdrawal of non-executed warrants, and updates to EU databases like SIS II. Training for legal practitioners, judicial networks, and a centralized case-law database were recommended to foster a European judicial culture. The resolution linked detention reforms to mutual trust, advocating EU-level initiatives to improve pre-trial standards. Financial implications were to be covered by existing budgets, with anticipated long-term savings from streamlined procedures. Overall, the resolution sought to strengthen mutual recognition instruments while safeguarding rights, proportionality, and legal certainty in the EU’s area of freedom, security, and justice.

title: European Protection Order: REPORT on the draft directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Protection Order
background: The European Union's framework for judicial cooperation in criminal matters, alongside disparities in national victim protection laws, highlighted challenges in cross-border enforcement of restraining orders. The Parliament will discuss establishing a mechanism for mutual recognition of protection orders across Member States to enhance victim safety within the EU area of freedom, security, and justice.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the draft directive’s focus on addressing cross-border custody disputes and protecting children from legal exploitation across Member States.  
EFD advises amending Article 4 to mandate domestic court validation of foreign protection orders, ensuring compatibility with national legal frameworks and local societal norms.  
EFD proposes reinforcing subsidiarity safeguards by requiring explicit justification for supranational enforcement mechanisms under Protocol No 2.  
EFD highlights the necessity of maintaining judicial sovereignty, suggesting periodic reviews to assess the order’s impact on national legal systems.  
 Contradictory EFD arguments reflect conditional support, balancing child protection goals with caution against supranational overreach.

GREEN_EFA totally upholds the issue’s urgent prioritization of combating gender-based violence, perfectly aligning with their unwavering commitment to safeguarding women’s rights and lives across Europe.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to transcend legal technicalities, emphasizing that protecting victims must supersede procedural delays, reflecting their principle of justice over bureaucratic inertia.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the directive’s potential to harmonize cross-border protection orders, advancing their manifesto goal of eradicating systemic violence through supranational solidarity.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the necessity for flexible implementation that respects national legal diversity while ensuring robust victim protections, mirroring their advocacy for adaptable yet uncompromising human rights frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the imperative to educate authorities and expand post-adoption efforts, resonating with their long-term vision for systemic change beyond legislative enactment.

ALDE firmly advocates the European Protection Order as a vital instrument to safeguard freedom and security across borders, perfectly aligning with ALDE's commitment to judicial cooperation and gender equality.  
ALDE highlights enhancement opportunities for future development of a European register of protection orders to ensure immediate application and cost efficiency while maintaining privacy standards.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s political boldness in advancing cross-border victim protection and urges refinement of translation support through the forthcoming victims’ rights package.  
ALDE emphasizes the directive’s critical role in protecting women from violence and urges expansion to address victims of organized crime in subsequent legislative measures.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s human rights focus, affirming its moral duty to uphold physical and psychological integrity as a universal principle within EU justice frameworks.

SD fundamentally supports the European Protection Order as a critical mechanism to eliminate cross-border protection gaps for victims of domestic violence, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to advancing freedom, security, and gender equality across the EU.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on harmonizing victim protection measures, ensuring legal certainty and immediate enforcement of orders to safeguard women fleeing threats or persecution in any Member State.  
SD fundamentally supports the integration of Article 3 of the Lisbon Treaty as a legal foundation, reinforcing the directive’s role in guaranteeing fundamental rights to security and dignity for all citizens within the European legal area.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of implementing the Protection Order to address systemic failures in judicial responsiveness to victims, particularly women, and to prevent cross-border impunity for perpetrators of gender-based violence.  
SD applauds the directive’s proactive approach to data collection, public awareness campaigns, and victim assistance frameworks, which directly advance SD’s priorities in combating trafficking, forced marriages, and honor crimes through institutional cooperation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on a legislative proposal concerning justice and home affairs, grounded in Treaty provisions including Article 76(b) and Article 82(1)(d) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), which establish EU competence in judicial cooperation and harmonization of criminal law. The resolution incorporated input from the Committee on Legal Affairs and addressed concerns from a national parliament challenging compliance with subsidiarity under Protocol No 2. It emphasized collaboration between the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, reflecting procedural adherence to Rule 51 of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure. The Parliament urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial amendments or replacements are planned, ensuring continued alignment with legislative intent and parliamentary oversight under Article 294 TFEU.

title: European Public Prosecutor's Office: INTERIM REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office
background: The European Union faced persistent challenges in safeguarding its financial interests, with annual fraud estimates exceeding €500 million, amid fragmented national enforcement and overlapping mandates of EU bodies like OLAF and Eurojust. The Parliament will discuss establishing a European Public Prosecutor’s Office under Article 86 TFEU to centralize prosecution of EU budget-related crimes.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, arguing that reinforcing national prosecutors’ coordination and training would more effectively combat EU budget fraud without creating bureaucratic redundancies.  
EFD opposes the proposal’s budgetary implications, emphasizing that allocating funds to a new institution during a crisis contradicts fiscal responsibility and strains member states’ resources.  
EFD fully challenges with the issue’s dismissal of competence clashes, warning that overlapping jurisdictions between the EPPO and national authorities will lead to legal uncertainty and inefficiency.  
EFD criticizes the undemocratic appointment process for the EPPO chief prosecutor, demanding greater parliamentary oversight to align with democratic accountability principles.  
 Слави Бинев (EFD) contradicts party stance by endorsing the EPPO as a safeguard against corruption in states like Bulgaria, though this view is isolated within EFD’s broader opposition.

GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the establishment of common procedural standards for cross-border investigations, aligning perfectly with their commitment to harmonized rights like legal interpretation and access to counsel as foundational for EPPO legitimacy.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s emphasis on data protection safeguards and urges prioritizing adoption of the EU data protection directive to prevent fragmentation, enhancing trust in EPPO operations.  

GREEN_EFA fundamentally endorses judicial independence and parliamentary oversight in EPPO leadership appointments, demanding amendments to Article 14 to require European Parliament confirmation of the chief prosecutor.  

GREEN_EFA emphasizes the critical need for Council engagement to avoid procedural gaps, proposing a structured consultation mechanism between legislative bodies to strengthen cooperation frameworks.  

GREEN_EFA urges enhancing EPPO staff training programs on digital evidence handling and transnational case management to address evolving fraud tactics while maintaining proportionality in investigative powers.

ALDE strongly upholds the establishment of the EPPO as a critical advancement in protecting EU financial interests, aligning with their longstanding commitment to European legal integration and combating cross-border fraud.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s emphasis on robust procedural safeguards and judicial oversight, proposing amendments to explicitly enshrine legal aid guarantees for defendants in line with ALDE’s human rights priorities.  
ALDE urges enhanced parliamentary scrutiny in the EPPO’s governance, advocating for amendments to ensure the European Parliament co-decides on the chief prosecutor’s appointment to strengthen democratic legitimacy.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of harmonized data protection standards across EPPO operations, calling for specific references to GDPR compliance in the regulation’s investigative protocols.  
ALDE highlights the need for binding cooperation frameworks with national judiciaries, recommending mandatory training modules to prevent competence overlaps while advancing cross-border judicial efficiency.

ECR opposes fundamentally the establishment of the EPPO as an EU-level body, asserting that prosecutorial authority must remain with national jurisdictions as emphasized by Ms. Tomašić's warning against dual legal hierarchies.  
ECR rejects the centralization of anti-fraud mechanisms, arguing with Mr. Nicholson that reinforcing national judicial efficiency through existing frameworks would better protect EU funds than creating costly new structures.  
ECR challenges the issue's compliance with subsidiarity principles, noting that overlapping competences criticized by both speakers directly contradict Article 86 TFEU's requirement for unanimous member state consent.  
ECR disputes the issue's assumption of improved fraud prevention, aligning with Mr. Nicholson's skepticism about whether the EPPO model effectively addresses the estimated €500 million annual losses compared to national alternatives.  
ECR condemns the proposed appointment process as undermining democratic accountability, reflecting concerns raised about insufficient parliamentary oversight in selecting the chief prosecutor.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) as a critical step to protect the EU’s financial interests, particularly against fraud costing €500 million annually in diverted funds from welfare and public services. It emphasized aligning the EPPO’s mandate with Article 86 TFEU to focus on crimes affecting the EU budget, while urging clarity on its relationship with Eurojust, OLAF, and national authorities to avoid overlapping competences and inefficiencies. The resolution called for robust procedural safeguards, including judicial review of OLAF investigations, legal aid for indigent defendants, and data protection standards, alongside balanced geographical and gender representation in EPPO staffing. It criticized the proposed appointment process for the EPPO as undemocratic, demanding greater parliamentary involvement in selecting the chief prosecutor and a transparent dismissal mechanism. Concerns were raised about potential opt-outs by Member States, which could create costly double structures, and the lack of a dedicated EU budget line or updated financial analysis to address resource needs for OLAF’s remaining anti-fraud tasks. The Parliament stressed the need for a coherent legal framework, including a European procedural law and a specialized criminal tribunal, to ensure legal certainty and avoid forum shopping. It highlighted the importance of training for EPPO staff and cooperation with national judiciaries, while urging the Council to prioritize thorough evaluation over rushed implementation and to enhance Member States’ judicial efficiency to support the EPPO’s success.

title: European Refugee Fund for the period 2008 to 2013 (amendment of Decision No 573/2007/EC): REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Decision No 573/2007/EC establishing the European Refugee Fund for the period 2008 to 2013 as part of the General programme "Solidarity and Management of Migration Flows" and repealing Council Decision 2004/904/EC
background: The European Refugee Fund (2008-2013) was established under Decision 573/2007/EC to support member states in asylum and migration management, forming part of the General Programme "Solidarity and Management of Migration Flows." The Parliament will discuss amendments to the fund’s implementation framework and financial provisions to address operational challenges during its designated period.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the proposal's alignment with Lisbon Treaty frameworks as absolutely conflicting with national sovereignty principles.  
EFD opposes the issue's solidarity mechanisms for failing to address systemic border control failures highlighted in Schengen area operations.  
EFD rejects provisions encouraging refugee resettlement, citing unresolved risks of economic migration exploitation under current EU policies.  
EFD absolutely conflicts with the issue's expanded asylum commitments, emphasizing Turkey's potential accession as exacerbating uncontrolled migration pathways.  
EFD opposes the legislative continuity approach, demanding treaty re-ratification to halt further EU integration as outlined in Article 294(3) TFEU procedures.

ALDE strongly agrees the expansion of refugee resettlement programs through enhanced ERF allocations, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to European solidarity and human rights protection.  
ALDE approves directing funds to local authorities for integration infrastructure, effectively advancing ALDE's priority of empowering municipalities to deliver housing and social services.  
ALDE endorses mandatory involvement of cities in implementation structures, recognizing their frontline role in refugee integration as emphasized in ALDE's local governance principles.  
ALDE commends the focus on vulnerable groups like women and children, mirroring ALDE's 2023 manifesto commitments to gender-sensitive asylum policies.  
ALDE proposes adding explicit safeguards in Article 4 to prevent national budget absorption, ensuring funds reach grassroots integration projects without opposing the overall funding mechanism.

SD strongly agrees the issue’s alignment with SD’s commitment to EU solidarity in refugee protection, particularly its emphasis on harmonizing resettlement programs through the European Asylum Support Office.  
SD approves the enhanced parliamentary oversight of ERF implementation, urging stricter transparency mechanisms for Member States’ use of funds to ensure compliance with humanitarian standards.  
SD emphasizes the critical need for coordinated EU-wide resettlement frameworks to address disproportionate burdens on southern Member States, aligning with Lisbon Treaty solidarity principles under Article 80 TFEU.  
SD proposes reinforcing interinstitutional cooperation on delegated acts to prevent procedural delays while maintaining full support for the ERF’s core objectives.  
SD strongly endorses the integration-focused amendments to the ERF, highlighting their consistency with SD’s advocacy for refugee rights and equitable burden-sharing across the Union.

GUE_NGL strongly approves the issue’s alignment with the Lisbon Treaty’s solidarity principles, advancing equitable refugee protection across Member States.  
GUE_NGL endorses enhanced parliamentary oversight to ensure migration funds prioritize humanitarian needs over securitized systems like SIS II.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending implementation guidelines to mandate rigorous data protection safeguards, preventing biometric overreach and unauthorized intelligence access.  
GUE_NGL underscores the necessity of auditing technical frameworks to avoid wasteful expenditures and ensure accountability in migration management tools.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes strict adherence to free movement principles, urging mechanisms to address disproportionate border checks that undermine Schengen commitments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on aligning interinstitutional decision-making procedures with the Treaty of Lisbon, particularly concerning asylum, immigration, and solidarity policies under Articles 78(2) and 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It endorsed the Commission’s proposal (COM(2009)0456) and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report (A7-0125/2010), emphasizing the need to adapt ongoing legislative processes to the Lisbon Treaty’s framework. The resolution underscored the legal basis of Article 294(3) TFEU for the ordinary legislative procedure and called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal if intending substantial amendments, ensuring parliamentary oversight. It further instructed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural continuity in light of the Lisbon Treaty’s implementation as outlined in COM(2009)0665.

title: European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation and Training (Europol): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation and Training (Europol) and repealing Decisions 2009/371/JHA and 2005/681/JHA
background: The Lisbon Treaty's entry into force required aligning Europol's legal framework with EU governance structures, replacing prior Council decisions. Cross-border crime complexities, evolving security threats, and operational coordination gaps necessitated updated mechanisms for law enforcement cooperation. The Parliament will discuss a proposed regulation establishing Europol's governance, operational mandates, and interagency cooperation frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the issue’s rejection of merging Europol and CEPOL, aligning with their longstanding commitment to preserving specialized law enforcement and training structures for optimal operational effectiveness.  
EPP fully agrees enhanced parliamentary oversight of Europol’s activities, ensuring democratic accountability while safeguarding data protection standards as mandated by the issue’s procedural safeguards.  
EPP applauds the prioritization of cybersecurity expertise within EC3, effectively advancing EPP’s priority to combat transnational cybercrime through specialized technical capacity and resource allocation.  
EPP proposes refining data-processing protocols under Amendment 128 to avoid excessive bureaucracy, ensuring Europol retains agility in combating organized crime while maintaining strict compliance with data protection rules.  
EPP strongly sanctions maintaining CEPOL’s operational independence through its Budapest relocation, recognizing its distinct role in advancing cross-border police training aligned with EU security objectives.

GREEN_EFA firmly supports the issue's integration of fundamental rights protections, perfectly aligning with their commitment to preventing surveillance overreach through the exclusion of direct private sector data access.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the enhanced parliamentary scrutiny mechanisms, recognizing these as critical to maintaining democratic oversight of Europol's expanded operational role.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports the clear separation between Europol and CEPOL, viewing this as essential to preserving specialized law enforcement training standards.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the binding commitment to annual budgetary reviews, ensuring resource allocation remains subordinate to legislative authority as demanded in their amendments.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's prohibition on processing illegally obtained data as a landmark achievement in upholding Charter of Fundamental Rights compliance.

SD strongly advocates extending Europol’s mandate to address evolving security challenges while emphasizing the necessity of robust procedural safeguards for fundamental rights.  
SD proposes enhancing the supervisory framework by establishing a joint oversight mechanism integrating national data protection authorities to ensure expertise and avoid fragmented accountability.  
SD underscores the critical alignment of Europol’s operational data handling with the highest EU standards, urging stricter definitions of "operational personal data" to prevent misuse.  
SD applauds the issue’s focus on institutional balance but stresses vigilance against historical overreach risks, advocating for annual audits of Europol’s data practices as a proactive enhancement.  
SD urges the Council to prioritize a unified, independent supervisory body for all EU justice and home affairs agencies to harmonize data protection without opposing the issue’s core objectives.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposed EDPS oversight mechanism as fundamentally inadequate, demanding joint supervisory bodies to prevent unchecked data authority consolidation.  
GUE_NGL opposes the absence of parliamentary removal powers in control procedures, deeming it incompatible with democratic accountability principles.  
GUE_NGL condemns the failure to grant explicit file access rights to oversight bodies, rendering scrutiny mechanisms "illusory" per transparency standards.  
GUE_NGL disputes the issue’s institutional balance claims, noting unresolved contradictions between Europol’s expanded mandate and Article 88 TFEU’s proportionality limits.  
GUE_NGL declares the framework’s safeguards "structurally deficient," citing unresolved risks of mission creep into non-core policing domains.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to extend Europol’s mandate while ensuring alignment with the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, particularly its point 31, which governs budgetary discipline and cooperation. It emphasized that extending Europol’s operational scope, including the European Cybercrime Centre (EC3), must not preempt annual budgetary decisions by the budgetary authority. The resolution called on the Commission to fully integrate the agreed regulatory framework into Europol’s budgetary and staffing plans, specifically addressing the EC3’s requirements as outlined in paragraph 42 of the 2012 Joint Statement on decentralized agencies. Additionally, Parliament insisted that any substantial amendments to the proposal or its replacement must be resubmitted for legislative review. The resolution underscored the necessity of adequate resources for Europol’s expanded tasks and reaffirmed procedural safeguards to maintain institutional balance.

title: European Year of Citizens (2013): REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Year of Citizens (2013)
background: The 2013 European Year of Citizens coincides with the 20th anniversary of EU citizenship established by the 1993 Maastricht Treaty, amid economic challenges and evolving rights under the 2009 Lisbon Treaty. The Parliament will discuss designating 2013 to enhance awareness of EU citizenship rights and promote civic participation across Member States.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the European Year of Citizens as a vital initiative to enhance awareness of EU rights, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to fostering European identity and integration through direct citizen engagement.  
EPP proposes complementing the focus on rights with structured dialogues about civic responsibilities, such as electoral participation, to deepen democratic accountability without opposing the issue’s core objectives.  
EPP applauds the emphasis on eliminating discriminatory national laws, which effectively advances EPP's priority of ensuring equal application of citizenship rights across all Member States.  
EPP strongly advocates leveraging the Year to differentiate EU citizenship from nationalist narratives, reinforcing Europe’s unique role in safeguarding daily protections and cross-border opportunities for citizens.  
EPP approves the issue’s alignment with Treaty-based rights expansion, particularly through awareness campaigns that clarify practical benefits like mobility and consular protections central to EPP’s integration agenda.

EFD rejects the concept of European citizenship as an imposed identity absolutely doubting with national sovereignty and self-determination principles.  
EFD opposes the issue's premise as propaganda attempting to legitimize EU overreach despite systemic failures like eurozone deflation and unemployment crises.  
EFD repudiates legislative efforts to expand Union citizenship frameworks, demanding withdrawal mechanisms consistent with their "exit the EU" platform.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as tax system disparities and regulatory imbalances enabling unfair competition under free movement provisions.  
EFD condemns the Year of Citizens initiative for disregarding public disillusionment evidenced by growing euroscepticism across member states.

SD strongly upholds the issue's focus on actionable citizenship rights, particularly aligning with SD's commitment to ensuring free movement, non-discrimination, and social solidarity across Member States.  
SD approves the emphasis on institutional accountability, urging enhanced mechanisms to address democratic backsliding and barriers faced by marginalized groups like Roma workers.  
SD proposes amending implementation timelines to mandate removal of labor restrictions for Romanian and Bulgarian workers by Q1 2013, reinforcing free movement principles.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of dedicated funding for citizenship education programs to combat misinformation and strengthen pan-European civic identity.  
SD highlights the critical role of local civil society engagement in operationalizing issue goals, aligning with SD’s grassroots democratic priorities.

ECR completely conflicts the European Year of Citizens initiative as a wasteful EU self-promotion exercise inconsistent with fiscal responsibility.  
ECR rejects the conflation of EU citizenship with national identity, viewing Article 2's citizenship provisions as undermining sovereign statehood.  
The proposal fails to address citizens' urgent economic needs, prioritizing symbolic programs over job creation and regulatory reform.  
ECR condemns allocating €5 million to this project during a sovereign debt crisis, demanding redirected funds to growth policies.  
This initiative exemplifies EU overreach, contradicting ECR's core principle of subsidiarity by centralizing civic engagement narratives.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2011 legislative proposal (COM(2011)0489), anchored in Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union Articles 294(2) and 21(2), following analysis by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and input from the Committees on Employment, Culture, Education, Constitutional Affairs, and Petitions. The resolution formally adopts Parliament’s stance, demands that the Commission re-engage legislators if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts, and mandates the Parliament’s President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural adherence and legislative coherence across EU institutions.

title: Report: Jan Philipp Albrecht - List of third States and organisations for Europol agreements: REPORT on the draft Council decision determining the list of third States and organisations with which Europol shall conclude agreements
background: The imminent entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, altering EU legal frameworks for police cooperation, prompted Council proposals to amend Europol's operational agreements with third states and organizations ahead of its transition to an EU agency. The Parliament will discuss the determination of third-state partners for Europol cooperation agreements.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the current proposal as it firmly doubts with the need to defer Europol reforms until the Lisbon Treaty establishes proper parliamentary oversight and legal coherence.  
EPP opposes the Council's text for preemptively amending Europol agreements without alignment to the Treaty of Lisbon’s democratic governance framework, which their members stressed as essential for legitimacy.  
EPP highlights contradictions in adopting "political" data-sharing measures now, arguing this undermines the Lisbon Treaty’s requirement for interinstitutional legislative coordination on security matters.  
EPP insists amendments must wait until the new treaty enables Parliament to properly scrutinize personal data transfers and operational protocols, as emphasized in debates about victim rights and procedural fairness.  
 While EPP members praised Europol’s work, they uniformly rejected adopting pre-Lisbon measures, framing delay as necessary to strengthen the agency under reformed legal parameters.

EFD rejects the issue's framework for Europol agreements, as sharing citizen data with states like Russia and Albania absolutely againsts with EFD's defense of national sovereignty and privacy rights.  
EFD opposes granting Europol officers legal immunity, a concept alien to British law and inconsistent with EFD's demand for accountable policing.  
EFD condemns the proposal’s expansion of EU police powers without public referenda, directly contradicting their principle of democratic consent for Lisbon Treaty measures.  
EFD highlights the issue’s failure to protect citizens from invasive data collection, including sexual preferences, which aligns with EU overreach EFD vehemently opposes.  
EFD warns that Europol’s integration undermines UK liberties, mirroring their longstanding rejection of EU judicial instruments like trials in absentia.

GREEN_EFA rejects the Council's proposal for failing to ensure colegislative parity with Parliament, absolutely rejecting with democratic accountability principles.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the centralized forensic coordination model, overlooking critical regional systems like Spain’s multi-laboratory structure.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s procedural haste, inconsistent with subsidiarity commitments to regional legal-police diversity.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal’s structural incompatibility with decentralized governance, a core GREEN_EFA priority since 2019.  
GREEN_EFA objects to the omission of territorial cohesion safeguards, directly contradicting their manifesto on multilevel justice cooperation.

SD firmly againsts the Council's Europol proposal for preemptively bypassing parliamentary authority under the imminent Lisbon Treaty framework, directly contradicting SD's commitment to democratic oversight in justice matters.  
SD rejects provisions allowing third-country data exchanges without defined "absolute necessity" criteria, conflicting with SD's data protection principles by enabling potential misuse of racial/ethnic classifications.  
SD highlights the proposal's legal insecurity in Article 15(2) regarding sensitive personal data handling, which dangerously endorses outdated racial categorization concepts contrary to SD's equality mandates.  
SD condemns the Council's procedural rush to adopt measures days before Lisbon Treaty implementation as a deliberate circumvention of Parliament's codecision powers over security architecture.  
SD demands complete withdrawal of the current text to prevent irreversible constraints on future parliamentary scrutiny of Europol's external agreements and database management protocols.

resolution: The European Parliament raised objections to the proposed Council text amending the Europol Decision, rejecting it due to the imminent entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which would establish a new legal framework for police cooperation. It argued that amendments to Europol’s implementing measures should be deferred until the Lisbon Treaty’s provisions take effect, ensuring alignment with the updated governance structure. The resolution called on the Council to withdraw its current proposal and urged the Commission or Council to present a revised Europol decision within six months of the Lisbon Treaty’s implementation, reflecting the reformed legal basis. Parliament emphasized its continued support for Europol’s mission but stressed the need for coherence with the forthcoming treaty framework, instructing its President to communicate this position to the Council and Commission.

title: Creation of an immigration liaison officers network: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 377/2004 on the creation of an immigration liaison officers network
background: Following the 2004 establishment of an EU immigration liaison officers network and subsequent creation of Frontex to coordinate border management, operational synergies between these entities remained unaddressed. The Parliament will discuss amending the 2004 regulation to improve cooperation mechanisms and information-sharing frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally upholds the integration of immigration liaison officers with Frontex operations, perfectly aligning with its commitment to robust border management and cross-border operational synergy.  
EPP applauds the issue’s emphasis on leveraging ICONet for secure data coordination, advancing its priority of technologically enhanced migration flow governance.  
EPP recognizes the network’s critical role in balancing legal immigration pathways and combating irregular flows, reflecting its dual approach to humane yet orderly migration systems.  
EPP commends the rapporteur’s excellence in achieving first-reading consensus, underscoring its institutional dedication to efficient justice and home affairs policymaking.  
EPP emphasizes the issue’s treaty compliance as a model for future initiatives, reinforcing its principle-driven stance on EU legislative coherence.

EFD rejects the immigration liaison officers network as incompatible with national sovereignty, citing Article 79(2)(c) TFEU's failure to prevent "uncontrolled EU immigration" undermining domestic labor markets.  
EFD opposes the issue's terminology shift from "illegal" to "irregular" immigration, arguing this semantic change obscures enforcement priorities in violation of their border security principles.  
EFD fundamentally rejects with the proposal's reliance on EU-level coordination, demanding unilateral Member State authority to impose caps on all immigrants regardless of origin.  
The proposal overlooks critical vulnerabilities where Member States naturalize undocumented migrants, creating systemic loopholes that the network cannot address.  
EFD condemns the issue's failure to prevent wage suppression and displacement of domestic workers, exemplified by undercutting practices enabled through unrestricted intra-EU movement.

SD completely upholds the enhanced transparency provisions, which align perfectly with SD’s commitment to accountable governance and parliamentary oversight of immigration liaison officers’ cross-border activities.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on integrating human rights safeguards into ILOs’ missions, ensuring asylum seekers’ protections remain central to EU external migration policies.  
SD applauds the negotiated compromise on terminology disputes, recognizing it as a critical step toward harmonizing operational clarity with fundamental rights imperatives.  
SD highlights the rapporteur’s inclusive consultation process as exemplary procedural rigor, reinforcing SD’s prioritization of collaborative interinstitutional lawmaking under Lisbon Treaty frameworks.  
SD unequivocally supports the issue’s unamended adoption, affirming its consistency with SD’s manifesto goals on migration justice and transnational accountability.

GUE_NGL fully challenges the repressive border control focus as incompatible with their principles of humane migration governance.  
GUE_NGL rejects the issue's failure to establish legal immigration channels, contradicting their demand for balanced policy frameworks.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal's inconsistency with treaty obligations to protect migrant rights under Article 79(2)(c) TFEU.  
GUE_NGL condemns the prioritization of Frontex/Schengen mechanisms over regularization pathways as perpetuating systemic exclusion.  
GUE_NGL asserts the Council compromise entrenches "illegal immigrant" stigmatization despite treaty-level recognition of irregular status.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning justice and home affairs, adopting its first reading stance as outlined in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs report (A7-0342/2010). The resolution emphasized alignment with relevant treaty provisions, including Article 79(2)(c) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which pertains to immigration policy, and Article 74 on ensuring cooperation in internal security. It urged the European Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or replacing the original text (COM(2009)0322), ensuring procedural continuity under the Treaty of Lisbon. The Parliament instructed its President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional accountability and adherence to legislative processes under the Treaties.

title: Motion for a resolution - Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA): JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the transparency and state of play of the ACTA negotiations
background: Confidential multilateral ACTA negotiations commenced in 2008 among EU and OECD states, raising concerns over transparency and legal alignment with EU data protection and intellectual property frameworks following the Lisbon Treaty's 2009 institutional reforms. The Parliament will discuss ACTA negotiation processes' compliance with EU transparency standards and legal obligations under international trade agreements.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA totally endorses the issue's demand for immediate transparency in ACTA negotiations, perfectly aligning with their foundational principle that democratic legitimacy requires open access to treaty documents as enshrined in Regulation 1049/2001.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's insistence on fundamental rights protections, particularly its rejection of warrantless device searches and "three-strikes" policies that violate Articles 7-8 of the EU Charter, echoing their decades-long advocacy for digital civil liberties.  

GREEN_EFA totally endorses the call for rigorous impact assessments on ACTA's compatibility with data protection frameworks like Directive 2002/58/EC, seeing this as critical to safeguarding citizens' privacy against disproportionate corporate interests.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with leveraging the Lisbon Treaty's Article 218 obligations to assert parliamentary oversight, viewing the issue's legal base requirements as essential to ending opaque "back-room politics" condemned in the debate.  

GREEN_EFA totally endorses reserving CJEU litigation to enforce institutional prerogatives, recognizing this as a necessary escalation to uphold democratic accountability when negotiating processes bypass elected representatives.

ALDE totally endorses the issue's demand for immediate transparency in ACTA negotiations, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to democratic oversight and public accountability as emphasized by Sophia in 't Veld's call for unrestricted document access.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue's rejection of warrantless device searches and 'three-strikes' policies, advancing ALDE's priority to protect fundamental digital rights as highlighted by Alexander Alvaro's concerns about privacy violations.  
ALDE fully supports requiring an impact assessment on data protection and e-commerce frameworks, effectively advancing ALDE's legislative priorities under Directives 2002/58/EC and 2000/31/EC as raised in parliamentary debate.  
ALDE endorses the issue's insistence on maintaining the *acquis communautaire*, perfectly reflecting Michael Theurer's emphasis on subsidiarity and preventing treaty misuse against individual freedoms.  
ALDE strongly affirms the right to pursue legal action through CJEU if prerogatives are undermined, aligning with ALDE's longstanding defense of institutional parity post-Lisbon Treaty as discussed across all interventions.

SD totally approves the issue’s insistence on absolute transparency in ACTA negotiations, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to democratic accountability under the Lisbon Treaty.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand to reject “three-strikes” policies and unwarranted device searches, reinforcing SD’s foundational stance on privacy rights under Articles 7-8 of the EU Charter.  
SD totally approves the call for immediate impact assessments on fundamental rights and data protection, advancing SD’s priority to safeguard digital freedoms enshrined in Directive 2002/58/EC.  
SD strongly supports the issue’s red lines against altering the *acquis communautaire*, echoing SD’s legislative redlines on IPR harmonization and intermediary liability protections.  
SD applauds the issue’s linkage of ACTA compliance with e-commerce safeguards under Directive 2000/31/EC, mirroring SD’s 2020 manifesto pledge for balanced digital governance.

GUE_NGL strongly accepts the issue’s demand for full transparency in ACTA negotiations, aligning perfectly with GUE_NGL’s longstanding commitment to democratic scrutiny and public accountability in international agreements affecting fundamental rights.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening the transparency mandate by requiring immediate publication of all negotiation texts to prevent corporate interests from overriding public access to medicines and digital freedoms.  
GUE_NGL approves the issue’s rejection of warrantless device searches and “three-strikes” policies, which effectively advance GUE_NGL’s priority to safeguard privacy rights under Articles 7-8 of the EU Charter.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the urgency of the issue’s impact assessment to expose ACTA’s threats to health equity, particularly regarding generic medicines, in line with their opposition to profit-driven IPR expansion.  
GUE_NGL urges explicit inclusion of parliamentary oversight mechanisms in future negotiation rounds to ensure compliance with Lisbon Treaty obligations, transforming secrecy into participatory democracy.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the lack of transparency and legal clarity in the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) negotiations, emphasizing the obligation under the Lisbon Treaty (in force since December 2009) for the Commission to fully inform Parliament at all stages. It criticized the absence of a prior legal base, parliamentary approval for the mandate, and public access to negotiation texts, urging the Commission and Council to disclose documents in line with EU transparency rules and Regulation 1049/2001. Parliament demanded proactive efforts to end confidentiality in negotiations, including placing transparency on the agenda of the April 2010 New Zealand round, and insisted on an immediate impact assessment of ACTA’s implications for fundamental rights, data protection (notably under Directive 2002/58/EC and the EU Charter), e-commerce (Directive 2000/31/EC), and ongoing IPR harmonization. It stressed that ACTA must align with the *acquis communautaire*, opposing warrantless searches of personal devices at borders and rejecting "three-strikes" internet policies, as incompatible with privacy (Articles 7-8 EU Charter) and Parliament’s prior amendments. While welcoming Commission assurances that ACTA would not alter substantive IP law, Parliament reserved the right to pursue legal action, including before the CJEU, to safeguard its prerogatives if not adequately informed.

title: Freezing and confiscation of proceeds of crime: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the freezing and confiscation of proceeds of crime in the European Union
background: Persistent challenges in effectively recovering criminal proceeds across the EU, driven by cross-border organized crime activities and disparities in national asset confiscation frameworks, highlighted systemic inefficiencies. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing measures to enhance freezing and confiscation of illicit gains, addressing legal gaps and improving transnational cooperation.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the directive’s framework for combating organized crime through extended confiscation measures, aligning with strategic priorities to disrupt criminal networks.  
EFD advises amending Article 5 to require a prior criminal conviction for asset confiscation, ensuring compliance with the presumption of innocence as enshrined in national constitutions like the UK Bill of Rights.  
EFD proposes establishing an EU-level monitoring mechanism under Article 7 to audit national implementations and prevent political misuse, citing documented irregularities in Bulgaria’s application of similar laws.  
EFD highlights the necessity of parallel reforms to border security policies, arguing that unchecked movement of criminals undermines the directive’s effectiveness in reducing cross-border crime.  
EFD urges explicit safeguards in Recital 12 to exempt member states where non-conviction-based confiscation violates constitutional protections, preserving national legal traditions.

GREEN_EFA absolutely accepts the directive's strengthened procedural safeguards that now guarantee fundamental rights protections against wrongful asset seizures.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's EU-level approach to combat organized crime's economic power, which drains resources from social and employment priorities.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the commitment to repurpose confiscated mafia assets as a vital tool to restore public trust in institutions and reinforce the rule of law.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the critical opportunity to operationalize voluntary mechanisms for redirecting illicit wealth into community-focused social programs.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue's coherence with their decade-long advocacy for systemic asset confiscation frameworks that deprive criminal networks of operational capital.

SD strongly agrees the directive's establishment of common minimum standards for freezing and confiscating criminal proceeds, aligning with their commitment to combat organized crime by targeting illicit assets.  
SD approves the inclusion of provisions allowing member states to use confiscated assets for social purposes, noting successful precedents in Italy and Ireland as models for EU-wide implementation.  
SD proposes that the Commission prioritize studying confiscation without final conviction in cases of defendant death where illicit origin is evident, urging rapid presentation of findings during the Italian Presidency.  
SD emphasizes the necessity for robust judicial oversight in all confiscation measures to safeguard defense rights, ensuring decisions remain under court authority as highlighted in cross-border cooperation.  
SD advocates for enhanced mutual recognition of freezing orders across member states to address asset concealment in transnational crime, reinforcing trust in EU judicial cooperation frameworks.

ECR partly accepts the directive’s aim to deprive criminals of illicit gains but demands amendments to mandate judicial oversight for all confiscations, addressing risks of abuse in states with weak rule of law.  
ECR supports expanded asset seizure targeting third-party transfers but insists on transparency safeguards to prevent political exploitation.  
ECR requests revisions to enforce unimpeded cross-border agency operations, condemning member state obstructions like the blocked National Crime Agency in Northern Ireland.  
ECR advocates redirecting confiscated assets to social programs for crime-affected communities, aligning with restorative justice principles.  
ECR highlights the need for explicit victim compensation clauses in Article 4 to ensure full restitution over state appropriation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading based on the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0085) concerning judicial cooperation in criminal matters and police cooperation under Treaty on the Functioning of the EU Articles 82(2) and 83(1), incorporating input from the European Economic and Social Committee, the Fundamental Rights Agency, and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report (A7-0178/2013). The resolution adopted Parliament’s stance, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments, and instructed its President to communicate the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments.

title: Fundamental rights in the European Union (2009) - Effective implementation after the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon: REPORT on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2009) – effective implementation after the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon
background: The Treaty of Lisbon's 2009 entry into force legally bound the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, establishing new legal obligations and institutional roles. The European Commission's 2010 strategy emphasized operationalizing the Charter, alongside ongoing EU negotiations to accede to the European Convention on Human Rights. The Parliament will discuss post-Lisbon implementation mechanisms for fundamental rights compliance across EU policies and member states.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA fundamentally sanctions the issue’s emphasis on leveraging the Charter’s binding force to transform foundational values into actionable rights, perfectly aligning with their commitment to judicial enforceability of equality principles.  

GREEN_EFA highlights the Roma rights case as a critical enhancement opportunity, urging future Commission interventions to robustly apply Article 21 of the Charter against discrimination alongside free movement rules.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the proposed early-warning system for rights violations, advocating its swift adoption to suspend contested measures during accelerated judicial review processes.  

GREEN_EFA emphasizes the need to institutionalize a UN-style Universal Periodic Review mechanism, reinforcing the issue’s call for proactive rights monitoring across EU policies.  

GREEN_EFA stresses that coherence in external agreements requires parliamentary oversight of readmission committees, aligning with the issue’s accountability mandates for EU institutions.

ALDE fundamentally endorses the issue’s emphasis on the legally binding Charter of Fundamental Rights, perfectly aligning with the party’s commitment to enforceable human rights frameworks and judicial accountability across EU institutions.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the call for a Commission-led freezing mechanism on contested national policies, recognizing its critical role in preventing human rights violations before legal enactment.  
ALDE fully supports the imperative to systematically monitor Member States’ compliance, including explicit “naming and shaming” procedures, as essential to maintaining EU credibility in global human rights advocacy.  
ALDE endorses the integration of minority protections, LGBT+ rights, and press freedom into fundamental rights reporting, advancing the party’s vision of inclusive, discrimination-free societies.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s alignment with international human rights standards, reinforcing the necessity of coherence between EU actions and UN/Council of Europe conventions.

SD fundamentally advocates the issue’s elevation of the European External Action Service as a global promoter of fundamental rights, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to advancing human rights diplomacy beyond EU borders.  
SD perfectly aligns with the report’s emphasis on the European Citizens’ Initiative, recognizing it as a transformative tool to empower citizens in shaping EU legislation post-Lisbon.  
SD fundamentally advocates the issue’s demand for rigorous Commission oversight of Member States’ adherence to the Charter, particularly in combating media censorship and safeguarding pension rights, reflecting SD’s unwavering stance on rule-of-law enforcement.  
SD perfectly aligns with the prioritization of child protection frameworks and disability rights strategies, underscoring SD’s manifesto-driven focus on eradicating exploitation and ensuring social inclusion.  
SD fundamentally advocates the issue’s condemnation of discriminatory opt-outs from the Charter, emphasizing that equal rights for Polish citizens align with SD’s core principle of universal dignity.

ECR rejects the issue's framework for fundamental rights enforcement as conflicting with subsidiarity principles.  
ECR opposes any Charter interpretation enabling EU competence expansion into national criminal justice systems.  
ECR fundamentally disputes the issue's coherence approach, citing irreconcilable differences between EU and ECHR judicial architectures.
