SD strongly upholds the issue’s condemnation of prolonged internal border controls, which aligns perfectly with their longstanding commitment to preserving free movement as a cornerstone of European integration.  
SD applauds the urgent call for Bulgaria, Romania, and Croatia’s Schengen accession, effectively advancing the principle of equality among member states and rectifying discriminatory delays that undermine EU cohesion.  
SD endorses the emphasis on reinforcing external borders through enhanced European Border and Coast Guard Agency capabilities and SIS reforms, crucial for maintaining Schengen’s security while upholding free movement.  
SD highlights the necessity of solidarity in asylum seeker relocation and swift CEAS reforms, strongly upholding measures that operationalize shared responsibility and compliance with fundamental rights.  
SD proposes amending the issue to include binding timelines for completing Schengen accession evaluations, ensuring technical readiness—not political obstruction—determines membership.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the issue's emphasis on biometric surveillance and physical barriers, which institutionalize racial profiling under the guise of border security.  
GUE_NGL opposes the expansion of interoperable databases and SIS reforms, arguing they prioritize policing over human rights and normalize mass surveillance of migrants.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to address systemic EU solidarity failures, as seen in France's abusive "controls au faciès" that pervert Schengen's free movement principles.  
GUE_NGL denounces the economic prioritization of border militarization (€500M+ on walls) while legal migration pathways and asylum solidarity remain neglected.  
GUE_NGL highlights contradictions in demanding CEAS reforms without binding relocation mechanisms, perpetuating border violence inconsistent with fundamental rights.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the prolonged and unlawful reintroduction of internal border controls by some Member States, which undermines Schengen principles, incurs significant economic costs (EUR 0.05–20 billion in one-off costs and EUR 2 billion annually), and harms free movement. It emphasized the need to strengthen external borders through measures like the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (EBCGA), systematic checks against databases, and the Schengen Information System (SIS) reform, including biometric capabilities. The resolution condemned the construction of over 1,200 km of physical barriers at EU borders, costing at least EUR 500 million, and urged compliance with the Schengen Borders Code. It highlighted critical deficiencies in implementing border controls, database interoperability, and the European Integrated Border Management (IBM) strategy, stressing the need for solidarity, shared responsibility for asylum seekers, and adherence to fundamental rights. Parliament called for swift reforms to the Common European Asylum System (CEAS), including relocation commitments, and urged Bulgaria, Romania, and Croatia’s accession to Schengen. It demanded stricter adherence to Schengen evaluation mechanisms, unannounced on-site visits, and improved search-and-rescue operations in the Mediterranean. Member States were urged to address migration challenges through legal pathways, combat human trafficking, and ensure data protection, while the Commission was tasked with enforcing infringement procedures and revising the EUROSUR regulation to enhance border surveillance and crisis response.

title: Asylum and Migration Fund: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Asylum and Migration Fund
background: Persistent migration pressures on EU member states, particularly frontline countries, and challenges in coordinating asylum and integration policies under existing mechanisms prompted the European Commission to propose a dedicated funding instrument. The Parliament will discuss establishing the Asylum and Migration Fund to address migration management and solidarity among member states.

stances.stance:
ENF totally doubts the allocation of €10+ billion for migrant relocation and legal pathways, viewing this as institutionalizing mass migration inconsistent with their sovereignty-first agenda.  
ENF rejects the issue's focus on "intercultural dialogue," arguing it dangerously ignores urgent needs to combat Islamic radicalization and defend European values like gender equality.  
ENF condemns continued funding for NGOs linked to George Soros, asserting these groups actively undermine border security through pro-migration activism.  
ENF declares the proposal a civilizational betrayal for prioritizing migrant integration over preserving Europe's cultural identity and demographic stability.  
ENF vows to mobilize public resistance against the issue, framing it as an existential threat to national sovereignty and security norms.

GREEN_EFA entirely sanctions the inclusion of funds for local authorities and communities, as this perfectly aligns with their commitment to grassroots solidarity and citizen-led humanitarian action across Europe.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s rejection of externalized containment strategies, ensuring the Fund adheres to human rights principles and avoids violations of EU foundational values.  
GREEN_EFA entirely sanctions the prioritization of integration measures and support for vulnerable individuals, advancing their manifesto goals of inclusive societies and dignity-driven migration policies.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call for strengthened intra-EU solidarity mechanisms, particularly fair responsibility-sharing and financial aid to frontline states, reflecting their advocacy for equitable burden distribution.  
GREEN_EFA entirely sanctions the transparency safeguards requiring parliamentary re-engagement on substantive amendments, upholding democratic oversight as central to their governance principles.

SD firmly agrees the integration-focused allocation of the Asylum and Migration Fund, perfectly aligning with S&D’s commitment to holistic migration governance that prioritizes vulnerable groups like minors and women through legal pathways.  
SD perfectly aligns with conditioning fund access on member states’ compliance with EU asylum law, transforming solidarity from rhetoric into a binding operational principle as mandated by treaty obligations.  
SD fully supports the €10.4 billion financial commitment to frontline states, recognizing that true security derives from integration strategies rather than border barriers, in line with S&D’s human-security doctrine.  
SD endorses decentralizing migration policy implementation to local authorities and civil society, advancing their manifesto priority to ground EU actions in grassroots human rights practices.  
SD emphasizes transparent solidarity metrics for fund distribution, proposing enhanced accountability mechanisms to address historical Council delays in establishing joint asylum frameworks.

ECR rejects the tripling of the Asylum and Migration Fund, arguing it incentivizes illegal migration and contradicts efforts to reduce arrivals.  
ECR opposes the focus on integration measures, citing decades of failed projects in Sweden and demanding mandatory assimilation policies instead.  
ECR demands that 85% of funds prioritize border enforcement and rapid repatriation of illegal migrants, rejecting "legal pathways" as counterproductive.  
ECR highlights the issue's failure to address overwhelmed frontline states like Greece, where returns must supersede integration spending.  
ECR fundamentally disputes with solidarity mechanisms, insisting financial support should enforce strict migration deterrence, not burden-sharing.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0471) concerning asylum and immigration policies under Articles 78(2) and 79(2) and (4) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It emphasized the need for a coordinated EU approach to migration management, including legal pathways and integration measures, while ensuring compliance with fundamental rights. The resolution, informed by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and incorporating opinions from the Committees on Development and Budgets (A8-0106/2019), called for strengthened solidarity mechanisms among member states, particularly through fair responsibility-sharing and financial support for frontline countries. It urged the Commission to maintain transparency by re-engaging Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the original text, ensuring legislative coherence and democratic oversight. The adopted position was forwarded to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to advance negotiations.

title: Asylum: provisional measures in favour of Italy and Greece: REPORT on the proposal for a Council decision amending Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 of 22 September 2015 establishing provisional measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece
background: Persistent migration pressures on Italy and Greece as EU entry points, coupled with the 2015 Council Decision establishing provisional relocation measures and subsequent EU-Turkey migration management agreements, prompted the European Commission to propose adjustments. The Parliament will discuss amending relocation mechanisms to address evolving operational challenges and solidarity obligations under international protection frameworks.

stances.stance:
EFDD partly promotes the proposal but underscores its failure to address binding enforcement mechanisms for member-state relocation quotas, directly contradicting Article 80 TFEU’s solidarity principles.  
EFDD opposes the diversion of relocation resources to the EU-Turkey resettlement scheme, which it deems inconsistent with equitable responsibility-sharing and a concession to flawed external migration policies.  
EFDD requests revisions to explicitly prohibit reallocating relocation slots for resettlement, amending Article 2 to prevent procedural cross-subsidization.  
EFDD highlights the proposal’s omission of sanctions for non-compliant states, urging amendments to introduce financial penalties under Article 78(3) TFEU.  
 EFDD critiques the issue’s reliance on voluntary pledges, framing it as a perpetuation of systemic failures in asylum governance.

SD strongly advocates the issue’s emphasis on solidarity and responsibility-sharing, aligning perfectly with their commitment to European integration and human rights protection.  
SD applauds the strengthened legal safeguards for asylum seekers, effectively advancing their priority of ensuring fundamental rights compliance across relocation mechanisms.  
SD endorses the improved relocation framework but proposes accelerating implementation timelines to address the 7,751 individuals awaiting transfer, prioritizing unaccompanied minors as a vulnerable group.  
SD underscores the critical need for standardized administrative procedures to overcome bureaucratic delays, ensuring member states fulfill existing commitments without further obstruction.  
SD calls for strict enforcement of relocation quotas, condemning the current inaction as incompatible with EU values and the issue’s solidarity principles.

ECR rejects the relocation mechanism as incompatible with voluntary member state participation principles enshrined in their sovereignty agenda.  
ECR opposes mandatory quotas that disregard distinctions between asylum seekers and economic migrants, contravening their border control priorities.  
ECR highlights the proposal's operational failure through sub-5% relocation completion rates, proving systemic unworkability per Article 78(3) implementation.  
ECR condemns implied sanctions against non-compliant states as EU overreach inconsistent with subsidiarity doctrines.  
ECR warns relocation incentives exacerbate Mediterranean crossings, directly conflicting with their "safe camps over redistribution" policy framework.

GUE_NGL strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on solidarity and responsibility-sharing, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to collective European action and equitable burden-sharing in migration crises.  

GUE_NGL approves the strengthened legal safeguards for asylum seekers and fundamental rights compliance, effectively advancing their priority of humane treatment and procedural justice for displaced populations.  

GUE_NGL proposes amending the legal basis to Article 78(2) TFEU to ensure full parliamentary co-decision, enhancing democratic accountability and ending reliance on emergency measures that sideline legislative oversight.  

GUE_NGL emphasizes the urgent need to operationalize relocation mechanisms, strongly upholding measures to hold member states accountable for meeting quotas and alleviating disproportionate pressures on Greece and Italy.  

GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s procedural transparency mandates, which align with their manifesto commitments to inter-institutional cooperation and rigorous enforcement of EU solidarity principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the amended Commission proposal (COM(2016)0171) to address migration under Article 78(3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing the need for solidarity and responsibility-sharing among member states. It endorsed modifications to strengthen legal safeguards for asylum seekers, improve relocation mechanisms, and ensure compliance with fundamental rights. The resolution called on the Commission to revise its proposal accordingly under Article 293(2) and urged the Council to consult Parliament again if intending to substantially alter the text, while also requiring notification of any deviations from Parliament’s approved position. Additionally, it instructed its President to formally transmit Parliament’s stance to the Council and Commission, underscoring procedural accountability and inter-institutional cooperation.

title: Enhanced cooperation: European Public Prosecutor's Office: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council regulation implementing enhanced cooperation on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (“the EPPO”)
background: Persistent cross-border financial crimes affecting the EU budget, including fraud and VAT evasion, highlighted gaps in existing judicial cooperation mechanisms. The European Commission proposed establishing a European Public Prosecutor’s Office under Article 86 TFEU, with 20 member states initiating enhanced cooperation due to lack of unanimity. The Parliament will discuss the draft regulation implementing this framework.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly promotes the establishment of the EPPO, particularly its inclusion of VAT fraud prosecution, aligning with their commitment to protecting EU financial interests and taxpayer funds.  
ALDE proposes linking access to EU structural funds to member states' participation in the EPPO framework to ensure shared responsibility in combating budgetary fraud.  
ALDE advocates for future expansion of the EPPO's mandate to address cross-border criminal threats such as terrorism and organized crime, enhancing judicial integration.  
ALDE applauds the EPPO's independent structure and operational efficiency as crucial steps toward building a unified European justice space that safeguards public welfare.  
ALDE urges non-participating member states to join the enhanced cooperation, emphasizing that cross-border crime demands transnational prosecutorial collaboration for collective security.

SD strongly agrees the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office as a landmark achievement in protecting EU financial interests, aligning perfectly with their commitment to combat cross-border fraud and safeguard taxpayer funds.  
SD proposes expanding participation mechanisms to incentivize all member states—particularly major EU fund recipients like Hungary and Poland—to join the enhanced cooperation, ensuring comprehensive protection of the EU budget.  
SD advocates extending the EPPO’s future mandate to address transnational organized crime and terrorism, building on its foundational role in combating VAT fraud and fund misappropriation.  
SD emphasizes strengthening procedural safeguards and judicial oversight provisions to maintain the EPPO’s operational independence while guaranteeing defendants’ rights across jurisdictions.  
SD recommends clarifying coordination protocols between the EPPO, OLAF, and national authorities to eliminate investigative gaps in non-participating states through reinforced data-sharing frameworks.

ECR firmly rejects the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office as an infringement on national judicial sovereignty, contradicting the principle of subsidiarity.  
ECR rejects the duplication of investigative frameworks, arguing the EPPO creates inefficiencies by operating parallel to Eurojust and OLAF rather than integrating with existing mechanisms.  
ECR condemns proposals to penalize non-participating states through budgetary discrimination, warning this undermines trust in EU cooperation structures.  
ECR asserts that prosecutorial authority must remain strictly with national institutions, viewing supranational overreach as incompatible with member state competence.  
ECR emphasizes that fraud combat requires strengthening national justice systems first, rather than creating centralized EU entities.

GUE_NGL entirely disputes the EPPO’s creation as an undemocratic centralization of judicial power, contradicting their defense of national sovereignty and cooperative justice.  
GUE_NGL rejects the proposal for failing to address concerns about overlapping mechanisms like Eurojust and OLAF, which already combat financial fraud without supranational overreach.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s inconsistency with subsidiarity principles by imposing complex competence disputes between national and European prosecutors.  
GUE_NGL condemns the unresolved oversight framework as a threat to procedural rights and constitutional safeguards in member states.  
GUE_NGL warns this accelerates harmful EU integration by eroding judicial autonomy through federalist structures lacking democratic accountability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the draft Council Regulation (09941/2017), submitted under Article 86 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (C8‑0229/2017), following the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ recommendation (A8-0290/2017), thereby endorsing the proposed legal framework. It formally approved the regulation, which establishes measures for enhanced judicial cooperation in criminal matters, and directed its President to communicate this decision to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments to ensure implementation.

title: Establishing a Programme for the Environment and Climate Action (LIFE): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Programme for the Environment and Climate Action (LIFE) and repealing Regulation (EU) No 1293/2013
background: The LIFE Programme (2014-2020) under Regulation (EU) No 1293/2013 supported environmental and climate initiatives. The European Commission proposed a 2021-2027 successor programme to align with EU climate neutrality goals, Paris Agreement commitments, and Sustainable Development Goals, emphasizing cross-sectoral integration. The Parliament will discuss establishing the updated LIFE Programme to advance environmental and climate action.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely sanctions the issue's prioritization of biodiversity protection through explicit inclusion of outermost regions in the BEST scheme, perfectly aligning with their 2023 manifesto commitment to safeguard Europe's unique ecosystems.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the strengthened cooperation mechanisms for third-country participation, recognizing this as vital for transboundary environmental challenges addressed in their Mediterranean Action Plan.  
EPP strongly advocates for the issue's emphasis on administrative simplification, viewing streamlined procedures as essential for maximizing LIFE's impact across all governance levels as outlined in their Digital Governance Strategy.  
EPP fully supports the proposed EUR 7 billion budget increase, noting it directly enables scaled replication of successful circular economy models championed in their Industrial Renewal Agenda.  
EPP emphasizes the critical importance of integrating agricultural stakeholders into climate resilience projects, reflecting their Farm to Fork policy's focus on sustainable land-use synergies.

EFDD rejects the allocation of LIFE Programme funds to climate-focused agricultural measures, asserting farmers cannot influence cosmic or solar drivers of climate change as outlined in Article 4.  
EFDD firmly condemns linking cohesion policy with climate objectives in the issue, stating this misdirects resources from tangible biosecurity improvements to ineffective atmospheric controls.  
The proposal overlooks critical EFDD priorities by neglecting to address antimicrobial resistance through targeted grants for flock culling and hardy livestock breeding as alternative budget uses.  
EFDD demands amendment of Section 2.3 to redirect 75% of biodiversity funding to combatting anti-microbial resistance in farming practices across outermost regions.  
This initiative contradicts EFDD's core principle that environmental spending must yield measurable impacts, not symbolic gestures toward uncontrollable natural climate variables.

ENF partially approves the LIFE Programme’s climate objectives but requests revisions to Article 5 to exclude subsidies for multinational corporations, citing misuse of taxpayer funds.  
ENF opposes extending the programme to third countries under current eligibility criteria, arguing this perpetuates financial exploitation of citizens for corporate gain.  
ENF demands amendments to prioritise direct household energy cost relief in vulnerable regions, rejecting the issue’s focus on administrative capacity-building as insufficient.  
ENF highlights contradictions with fiscal responsibility principles, insisting on binding clauses to prevent cohesion policy alignment from inflating energy bills for low-income families.  
ENF fundamentally disputes the BEST scheme’s structure, proposing strict auditing mechanisms to ensure subsidies benefit local ecosystems, not “bankers and multinationals”.

SD entirely accepts the LIFE Programme's expanded financial allocation as indispensable for achieving EU climate neutrality, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to binding environmental targets and the Paris Agreement's decarbonization imperatives.  
SD emphasizes that the BEST scheme's prioritization of biodiversity in outermost regions directly advances SD's climate justice principles by ensuring equitable resource distribution for vulnerable ecosystems.  
SD highlights the issue's integration of circular economy subprograms as a transformative catalyst for systemic resource efficiency reforms, mirroring SD's 2024 manifesto pledge for industrial ecology transitions.  
SD applauds the mandatory project communication strategies as critical for amplifying citizen engagement on climate action, requiring structured coordination between municipalities and civil society groups.  
SD stresses that extending LIFE to third countries under strict EU priority alignment creates vital leverage points for globalizing SD's Green Deal leadership model without compromising regulatory standards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of its position on the LIFE Programme, emphasizing enhanced environmental and climate action funding, particularly for the Outermost Regions and Overseas Countries and Territories through the Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services in Territories of European Overseas (BEST) scheme. The resolution prioritizes cooperation, best practice development, and extending the program to third countries under specified conditions, including former EU member states. It stresses alignment between cohesion policy and LIFE Programme objectives, advocates for a stronger role for regional and local authorities in implementation, and supports administrative capacity-building projects. The Parliament underscored the necessity of targeted environmental funding for vulnerable regions and clarified eligibility criteria for third-country participation to ensure coherence with EU priorities.

title: Establishing a centralised system for the identification of Member States holding conviction information on third country nationals and stateless persons (TCN) to supplement and support the European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS-TCN system): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a centralised system for the identification of Member States holding conviction information on third country nationals and stateless persons (TCN) to supplement and support the European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS-TCN system) and amending Regulation (EU) No 1077/2011
background: The European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS) lacked efficient mechanisms to identify prior convictions of third-country nationals (TCNs) and stateless persons in the EU, creating gaps in cross-border judicial cooperation. The Parliament will discuss establishing a centralized identification system to address these limitations and improve information-sharing among Member States.

stances.stance:
ALDE firmly supports the issue's safeguards ensuring equal treatment between EU nationals and third-country nationals through harmonized fingerprint collection standards.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the exclusion of non-EU convictions, maintaining the system's focus on intra-EU judicial efficiency and data protection.  
ALDE strongly advocates the prohibition of racial profiling by mandating systematic checks rather than discretionary searches.  
ALDE commends the legal certainty provided by uniform implementation across Member States, preventing fragmentation in judicial practices.

SD strongly promotes the establishment of the centralized ECRIS-TCN system as a crucial step toward enhancing judicial cooperation and cross-border information exchange, aligning with their commitment to effective EU-wide criminal record management.  
SD emphasizes the need to strengthen anti-discrimination safeguards in Article 6 to prevent differential treatment between EU citizens and third-country nationals, ensuring equal procedural protections regardless of citizenship status.  
SD proposes clarifying interoperability boundaries in Recital 12 to explicitly limit data usage to conviction-related judicial purposes, preventing mission creep into unrelated security domains.  
SD approves the issue’s alignment with fundamental rights frameworks but urges mandatory audits to verify non-discrimination compliance in all member states’ implementation practices.  
SD welcomes the cross-border collaboration mechanisms as advancing justice priorities while recommending biometric data guidelines to prevent disproportionate fingerprinting of third-country nationals.

ECR strongly promotes the establishment of a centralized conviction database for third-country nationals, closing critical loopholes that previously allowed non-EU criminals to evade cross-border judicial scrutiny.  
ECR approves the inclusion of fingerprint biometrics as a vital enhancement to ensure unambiguous identification of individuals with criminal records across borders.  
ECR endorses the issue’s treatment of dual nationals, emphasizing that EU citizenship must not shield those with convictions under third-country identities from accountability.  
ECR highlights the system’s urgency in countering security threats posed by returning foreign fighters, aligning perfectly with ECR’s commitment to preemptive judicial cooperation against terrorism.  
ECR commends the streamlined inter-state data requests as a decisive step to replace fragmented national procedures, effectively advancing ECR’s priority of operational efficiency in law enforcement.

GUE_NGL strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on fundamental rights compliance and procedural safeguards, aligning with their commitment to protecting individual liberties in cross-border judicial cooperation.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Article 8 to explicitly prohibit the use of conviction data for migration enforcement purposes, ensuring strict adherence to proportionality and non-discrimination principles.  
GUE_NGL underscores the necessity of limiting supranational data centralization, advocating for robust oversight mechanisms to prevent misuse under expansive security frameworks.  
GUE_NGL endorses the issue’s potential to standardize rights protections across Member States, countering fragmented practices that risk undermining constitutional safeguards.  
GUE_NGL highlights the urgency of clarifying "terrorism" definitions in Annex II to prevent overreach, aligning with their opposition to securitized migration policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2017 proposal (COM(2017)0344) to strengthen judicial cooperation in criminal matters, particularly through measures aligned with Article 82(1)(d) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution endorsed adopting legal frameworks to enhance cross-border collaboration, procedural safeguards, and efficient resource allocation, while emphasizing compliance with fundamental rights. It called for consistent implementation across member states, urged the Commission to uphold Parliament’s position during further negotiations, and stressed the need to avoid fragmentation in judicial practices. The resolution also highlighted forwarding the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure alignment and facilitate coherent legislative progress.

title: Establishing the Rights and Values programme: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Rights and Values programme
background: Rising concerns over challenges to EU foundational values in member states, including rule of law disputes, attacks on judicial independence, media freedom, and civil society, alongside reported incidents of violence against activists and journalists, prompted institutional commitments to reinforce democratic principles. The Parliament will discuss establishing a dedicated Rights and Values programme to promote EU values and support civil society initiatives.

stances.stance:
EPP supports the tripled budget allocation and simplified funding procedures, emphasizing their alignment with strengthening civil society and democratic participation across member states.  
EPP endorses the program’s preventive approach to safeguarding EU values, particularly in countering judicial interference and media freedom erosion highlighted in Articles 19(2) and 21(2) TFEU.  
EPP advises enhancing educational components in Article 167 provisions to address youth awareness gaps, ensuring projects directly counter disinformation about EU principles.  
EPP suggests amending Clause 4 to explicitly reference the Istanbul Convention, reinforcing commitments to gender equality and violence prevention as outlined in the 2023 EPP manifesto.  
EPP cautions that NGO funding mechanisms must include strict neutrality checks under Article 3 to prevent partisan misuse, ensuring transparency in budget allocations.

ENF rejects the Rights and Values programme’s delegation of EU priorities to NGOs, completely opposeing with ENF’s demand for direct institutional accountability in safeguarding European sovereignty.  
ENF opposes the financial prioritization of third-party entities like Open Arms, citing explicit contradictions with ENF’s principles against subsidizing organizations that circumvent national immigration laws.  
ENF condemns the proposal’s moral ambiguity in funding NGOs, which overlooks critical risks of enabling non-aligned agendas that undermine member states’ jurisdictional authority.  
ENF disputes the programme’s alignment with TFEU Article 168, arguing it institutionalizes reckless outsourcing of public health and security mandates to unaccountable private actors.  
ENF challenges the issue’s claim to uphold the rule of law, asserting that its support for NGOs engaged in human trafficking facilitation directly violates ENF’s core stance on border integrity.

SD strongly endorses the increased financial allocation to civil society organizations combating racism, xenophobia, and gender-based violence, aligning with SD’s commitment to social justice and inclusive democracies.  
SD approves the program’s focus on youth education to foster tolerance and diversity, directly advancing SD’s priority of building pluralistic citizenship through formal and informal learning.  
SD endorses the emphasis on grassroots democratic participation as critical to countering authoritarian erosion of rule-of-law principles in Hungary and Poland, reflecting SD’s manifesto against illiberal regimes.  
SD proposes enhancing Article 4 to explicitly prioritize intercultural and interreligious dialogue in citizenship-building initiatives, reinforcing societal cohesion without opposing the program’s core objectives.  
SD applauds the linkage between EU funding and adherence to democratic values, which aligns with SD’s longstanding advocacy for conditionality mechanisms to protect civil liberties.

ECR rejects the Rights and Values programme for disproportionately targeting protections for specific groups while systematically excluding safeguards for Europe’s Christian heritage, directly contradicting Treaty-recognized religious values.  
ECR opposes the allocation of €2 billion to NGOs, arguing this enables fund mismanagement akin to migration-related spending failures, instead demanding resources for job creation and municipal institutions to restore economic dignity.  
The proposal absolutely opposes with ECR’s principle of subsidiarity by centralizing cultural governance, mirroring Viktor Orbán’s warnings about EU overreach into “managed democracy” frameworks.  
ECR condemns the issue’s omission of anti-Christian hostility despite 556 documented attacks on Greek Orthodox institutions in 2017, exposing a discriminatory bias in Article 11’s selective hate-crime priorities.  
The programme’s singular focus on gender ideology and LGBTQ+ advocacy overlooks critical aspects such as workplace stability and youth employment, which ECR deems foundational to societal cohesion.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal (COM(2018)0383) under Treaty provisions related to non-discrimination, cultural diversity, public health, and institutional competencies. It emphasized alignment with legal bases under Articles 16(2), 19(2), 21(2), 24, 167, and 168 of the TFEU, addressing civil liberties, justice, cultural and educational policies, gender equality, employment, social affairs, legal frameworks, and constitutional matters. The resolution integrated inputs from multiple committees, including Civil Liberties, Culture and Education, Women’s Rights, Budgets, Employment, Legal Affairs, and Constitutional Affairs, reflecting a cross-sectoral approach. It formally adopted its first-reading stance and urged the Commission to re-submit the proposal to Parliament if substantial revisions or replacements occur, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural accountability. The resolution also mandated communication of its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional dialogue.

title: European Border and Coast Guard: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Border and Coast Guard and repealing Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004, Regulation (EC) No 863/2007 and Council Decision 2005/267/EC
background: Increased migration flows, security challenges, and fragmented external border management within the Schengen Area prompted the European Commission to propose enhancing Frontex's mandate. The Parliament will discuss establishing a European Border and Coast Guard to strengthen integrated border controls, improve crisis response capacity, and address vulnerabilities in external border surveillance.

stances.stance:
EPP totally endorses the establishment of the European Border and Coast Guard as a vital reinforcement of Schengen security, perfectly aligning with its commitment to effective external border management while respecting national sovereignty.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s operational framework, emphasizing rapid deployment capabilities and enhanced Frontex resources to address migration pressures decisively.  
EPP totally endorses the harmonized approach to returns and search-and-rescue operations, which advances its priority of combating human trafficking while upholding fundamental rights.  
EPP strongly agrees the issue’s balance between shared EU responsibility and member state competence, ensuring solidarity without undermining national border control authority.  
EPP applauds the inclusion of children’s rights protections in border operations, reflecting its manifesto commitment to safeguarding vulnerable groups during migration management.

ENF rejects the establishment of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency as a direct assault on national sovereignty, absolutely disapproveing with their principle that border control must remain under exclusive member state authority.  
ENF opposes the mandatory liaison officers outlined in the proposal, condemning them as surveillance tools inconsistent with ENF's demand for unmonitored national autonomy in migration policy.  
The proposal's reliance on EU integration to address migration failures overlooks critical ENF priorities such as reinstating internal borders and adopting pushback policies modeled on Australia.  
ENF condemns the issue's continuation of Schengen's open borders as morally bankrupt, directly contradicting their call to return border authority to sovereign nations.  
The centralized enforcement mechanisms in the proposal are denounced by ENF as coercive overreach, irreconcilable with their vision of Europe as a coalition of independent states.

GREEN_EFA rejects the European Border and Coast Guard proposal as structurally incompatible with human rights priorities, citing its failure to mandate life-saving search and rescue operations at sea.  
GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the "Frontex+" model for prioritizing border militarization over refugee protection frameworks, directly contradicting their manifesto commitment to "safe passage first" policies.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's jurisdictional contradictions through practical examples like cross-border enforcement ambiguities, proving its inconsistency with accountable governance principles.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the accelerated legislative process as procedural negligence that undermines refugee dignity, noting the absence of mandated asylum officer reinforcements or medical care provisions.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the proposal's failure to create legal migration pathways, directly conflicting with Commissioner Avramopoulos' stated goals while maintaining exclusionary border regimes.

SD firmly endorses the establishment of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency as a vital step towards shared responsibility in border management, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to European solidarity and integrated migration frameworks.  

SD perfectly aligns with the enhanced fundamental rights protections in the regulation, particularly the strengthened complaint mechanism and specialized safeguards for children and vulnerable persons, reflecting SD's core principles of human dignity in border operations.  

SD firmly endorses the agency's expanded search and rescue mandate in maritime operations, recognizing this as a moral imperative that advances SD's vision of humanitarian EU border management while maintaining free movement within Schengen.  

SD perfectly supports the reinforced parliamentary oversight provisions ensuring accountability to EU institutions, which aligns with SD's democratic governance priorities and transparency requirements for EU agencies.  

SD firmly endorses the regulation's approach to addressing migration holistically through operational coordination with EASO and Europol, viewing this as foundational for future development of a common European asylum system as advocated in SD policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the European Commission’s 2015 proposal (COM(2015)0671) concerning EU policies on border controls, legal immigration, and asylum under Articles 77(2)(b) and (d) and Article 79(2)(c) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution, informed by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report and opinions from the Committees on Foreign Affairs, Budgets, and Fisheries, formally adopted Parliament’s stance on the legislative proposal. It urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if intending to amend or replace the proposal substantially and directed the Parliament’s President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing procedural adherence while focusing on harmonizing EU migration and border management frameworks.

title: European Public Prosecutor's Office: INTERIM REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office
background: Persistent concerns over fraud affecting EU financial interests, estimated at €500 million annually (potentially up to €3 billion), low prosecution rates of OLAF-referred cases (31% in 2006-2013), and disparities in Member States’ enforcement efficiency prompted calls for centralized oversight under Article 86 TFEU. The Parliament will discuss establishing a European Public Prosecutor’s Office to address cross-border fraud.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly upholds establishing a robust EPPO with uniform procedural standards, aligning perfectly with their commitment to cross-border judicial integrity and fundamental rights protection.  
GREEN_EFA urges rejecting diluted proposals for a network-type structure, advocating instead for centralized decision-making to ensure operational effectiveness against VAT fraud and corruption.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s emphasis on judicial review mechanisms, which advance their priority of safeguarding fair trial rights and preventing prosecutorial overreach.  
GREEN_EFA proposes explicitly excluding political interference in the EPPO’s mandate to counter attempts by certain governments to undermine its anti-corruption role.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the EPPO as a sovereignty-enhancing innovation, mirroring international judicial cooperation models they have long championed.

SD firmly approves the establishment of an independent European Public Prosecutor’s Office as a critical mechanism to combat systemic fraud, perfectly aligning with SD’s longstanding commitment to safeguarding EU financial interests through supranational judicial accountability.  

SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand for transparent merit-based selection of EPPO leadership, emphasizing that parliamentary involvement in appointments is essential to prevent national interference and uphold institutional credibility.  

SD firmly approves the imperative to harmonize evidence admissibility rules across Member States, recognizing this as foundational to eliminating procedural fragmentation and ensuring equal protection of EU budgetary integrity.  

SD strongly promotes the call to expand EPPO’s mandate to cross-border crimes like organized crime, viewing this as a logical extension of its fraud-combat role and consistent with SD’s broader agenda for integrated judicial cooperation.  

SD emphasizes that the issue’s safeguards for defendants’ rights—including judicial review and non-bis-in-idem protections—must be non-negotiable, aligning with SD’s principled defense of procedural fairness even in high-stakes anti-corruption cases.

ECR rejects the establishment of the EPPO as it infringes on national sovereignty, contradicting the issue's push for centralized prosecution authority. The EU's lack of statehood makes a European prosecutor institutionally incompatible.  
ECR opposes expanding prosecutorial powers to cross-border crimes, arguing this duplicates Eurojust's mandate and creates unnecessary bureaucratic overlap, contrary to the issue's harmonization goals.  
ECR fundamentally objects to budget allocation for the EPPO, viewing it as wasteful when existing mechanisms like OLAF could be strengthened instead, opposing the issue's resource commitments.  
ECR challenges the legal basis for EPPO's creation, noting treaty requirements for unanimous member state approval which the issue's centralized model fails to accommodate.  
ECR condemns the proposal as part of a broader EU overreach into national judicial systems, directly conflicting with the issue's presumption of harmonized legal standards across sovereign states.

GUE_NGL completely againsts with the issue's centralization of prosecutorial powers, opposing any EU-level body overriding national judicial sovereignty as stated in Article 2.  
GUE_NGL rejects the EPPO's jurisdictional framework for violating subsidiarity principles, echoing 11 member states' yellow card objections regarding crime prioritization (Recital 9).  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of legal certainty by allowing parallel EU/national prosecutions, contradicting GUE_NGL's defense of non-bis-in-idem protections in Article 7.  
GUE_NGL opposes the merit-based leadership selection process (Article 12) as enabling supranational overreach inconsistent with accountable national justice systems.  
This issue fails to address forum shopping risks through centralized evidence rules (Article 5), which GUE_NGL argues would destabilize defendant rights across jurisdictions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about significant fraud risks to the EU’s financial interests, estimating annual losses at €500 million, with potential exposure up to €3 billion, and highlighted a low 31% indictment rate for fraud cases between 2006-2013. It emphasized the need for an independent European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) to address these gaps, ensuring uniform prosecution across Member States despite differing legal systems. The resolution called for a decentralized EPPO structure with central decision-making on jurisdiction, investigations, and prosecutions, stressing judicial review of its decisions to safeguard rights like fair trials, presumption of innocence, and non-bis-in-idem. It demanded transparent, merit-based selection of EPPO leadership with Parliament’s involvement, clear delineation of competences between EPPO, Eurojust, Europol, and OLAF, and harmonized rules for evidence admissibility. The Parliament urged expanding the EPPO’s mandate to include cross-border crimes like terrorism and organized crime, while ensuring annual reporting and budget accountability. It also highlighted the need to avoid overlaps with national prosecutors, prevent forum shopping, and guarantee redress for wrongful prosecutions, aligning EPPO operations with EU fundamental rights and judicial standards.

title: Humanitarian visas: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on Humanitarian Visas
background: Persistent absence of EU-wide humanitarian visa frameworks led to high irregular migration, with 90% of international protection recipients entering through unsafe routes, resulting in over 30,000 deaths at EU borders since 2000 and heightened risks for vulnerable groups. The Parliament will discuss establishing legal pathways for safe entry to address asylum access challenges.

stances.stance:
EPP completely againsts the humanitarian visa framework as it bypasses national asylum eligibility assessments before entry  
EPP rejects the proposal's failure to mandate prior security screenings at consulates, creating unacceptable border control vulnerabilities  
EPP highlights operational infeasibility given current consular capacities, risking systemic collapse from application surges  
EPP condemns the EU-level encroachment on member states' sovereign asylum procedures as incompatible with subsidiarity principles  
EPP emphasizes alignment with past migration management failures where uncontrolled entry overwhelmed verification mechanisms

SD strongly sanctions the creation of a European Humanitarian Visa framework as a vital alignment with SD’s commitment to human rights and safe migration pathways, directly addressing the lethal gaps in current asylum access.  
SD applauds the gender-sensitive procedural requirements for assessing persecution related to gender-based violence, advancing SD’s priority of protecting women and LGBTQI+ individuals from systemic vulnerabilities.  
SD endorses the 15-day processing timeline and appeal mechanisms as essential safeguards to balance efficiency with due process, reflecting SD’s principles of fairness in migration governance.  
SD proposes enhancing family reunification clarity by explicitly defining eligibility criteria in Article 4 to prevent ambiguity while respecting national asylum protocols, as highlighted in parliamentary deliberations.  
SD emphasizes the imperative of EU-funded implementation under Article 80 TFEU to ensure equitable burden-sharing, mirroring SD’s longstanding advocacy for solidarity-driven migration policies.

ECR rejects the humanitarian visa proposal as fundamentally incompatible with national sovereignty over migration policy, citing Article 80 TFEU's subsidiarity principle.  
ECR opposes the EU-level harmonization attempt, arguing it creates security loopholes exemplified by the Manchester bomber case involving Schengen visa abuse.  
This conflicts with ECR's stance that asylum systems are already exploited, noting Branislav Škripek's evidence of 88,000 Maltese-issued visas to Libyans as precedent for abuse risks.  
The proposal overlooks ECR's priority to combat migration root causes (poverty/war) rather than creating "incentives" through new entry channels, per Νότης Μαριάς' poverty-migration linkage argument.  
ECR challenges the 15-day processing window as operationally unfeasible, citing Ruža Tomašić's insistence on national discretion over asylum procedures and cost burdens.

GUE_NGL strongly endorses the establishment of a European Humanitarian Visa framework, aligning perfectly with its longstanding commitment to dismantling deadly irregular migration routes and upholding solidarity as a core EU principle.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening Article 80 TFEU financial solidarity mechanisms to ensure full EU coverage of visa processing costs, preventing fiscal burdens from deterring member state participation.  
GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s gender-sensitive assessment protocols, which effectively advance the party’s priority of protecting women and LGBTQI+ individuals from systemic violence during asylum processes.  
GUE_NGL suggests amending procedural timelines to mandate faster security screenings while preserving appeal rights, addressing concerns about bureaucratic delays exacerbating vulnerabilities.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the urgency of harmonizing national humanitarian visa schemes with the EU framework to prevent fragmentation and ensure consistent access to protection across all member states.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for a Union-level legal framework to establish a European Humanitarian Visa, addressing the absence of harmonized safe pathways for individuals seeking international protection. Highlighting that 90% of those granted protection arrive irregularly, leading to stigmatization and risks such as exploitation, gender-based violence (noting women’s heightened vulnerability), and over 30,000 deaths at EU borders since 2000, the resolution called on the Commission to propose a regulation by March 2019. This visa would allow third-country nationals at risk of persecution or harm to enter a Member State solely to apply for asylum, complementing—not replacing—existing national humanitarian entry schemes and resettlement programs. The proposed visa would require streamlined procedures: applications via embassies/consulates, security screenings, a 15-day processing window, appeal rights, and gender-sensitive assessments recognizing persecution based on gender-based violence (e.g., rape, forced marriage). Financial solidarity under Article 80 TFEU was emphasized, with EU funds covering costs, mirroring resettlement compensation. The resolution stressed the need for safe routes to reduce irregular migration, protect vulnerable groups (women, LGBTQI+ individuals, disabled persons), and align with international obligations, including the Refugee Convention and Istanbul Convention. It condemned unsafe practices like "disembarkation platforms" and urged gender-disaggregated data collection, specialized training for staff, and ratification of the Istanbul Convention by all Member States.

title: Follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 12 March 2014 on the electronic mass surveillance of EU citizens: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 12 March 2014 on the electronic mass surveillance of EU citizens
background: Revelations of electronic mass surveillance programs affecting EU citizens, the 2014 European Parliament resolution on NSA activities, subsequent inquiries, and the 2015 CJEU ruling invalidating the Safe Harbour Decision highlighted concerns over data privacy. The Parliament will discuss balancing national security objectives with fundamental rights protections in electronic surveillance and cross-border data transfers.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's conflation of mass surveillance concerns with unrelated ideological demands, such as suspending TTIP negotiations or mandating open-source software adoption, which divert focus from core security-privacy balance.  
EPP opposes the proposal to impose blanket sunset clauses on surveillance laws as disproportionate and operationally disruptive, advocating instead for adaptable frameworks with rigorous parliamentary oversight.  
EPP fundamentally disputes the issue's call to limit EU-US counter-terrorism tools like TFTP, stressing that such measures jeopardize transatlantic security cooperation vital to combating cybercrime and terrorism.  
EPP condemns the issue's failure to prioritize actionable reforms like strengthening Europol's cybercrime center or establishing EU-level intelligence coordination mechanisms over symbolic gestures like Snowden amnesty demands.  
EPP challenges the issue's neglect of proportionality in data transfer reforms, arguing that rigid data localization requirements would undermine both EU-US trade relations and operational security needs.

ALDE strongly endorses the issue's condemnation of mass surveillance as fundamentally incompatible with EU values, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to privacy and data protection as non-negotiable rights.  
ALDE applauds the emphasis on CJEU jurisprudence regarding Safe Harbour, urging immediate adoption of robust EU-US data transfer mechanisms that prohibit bulk collection practices.  
ALDE proposes enhancing Article 9 to mandate quarterly Commission reporting on member state surveillance law compliance, ensuring sustained parliamentary oversight of national intelligence reforms.  
ALDE urges accelerated implementation of the Data Protection Package and digital autonomy strategies, condemning the Commission's delayed response to Parliament's 2014 recommendations as undermining citizen trust.  
ALDE demands binding safeguards for legal professionals and journalists against surveillance overreach, citing the Prakken d'Oliveira ruling as a model for independent judicial review frameworks.

ECR rejects the issue's call to suspend anti-terror agreements with the United States as fundamentally incompatible with their prioritization of security cooperation amid heightened threats in Europe.  
ECR opposes the issue's jurisdictional overreach, asserting that national security remains an exclusive member state competence under EU treaties, rendering Parliament's surveillance recommendations illegitimate.  
ECR condemns the issue's failure to uphold core Western legal principles by implicitly accepting state surveillance as default, directly contradicting their belief in strictly limiting government intrusion into civil liberties.  
ECR disputes the issue's reliance on unverified investigative findings from politically motivated inquiries lacking access to classified documents or sworn testimony.  
ECR dismisses the issue's focus on symbolic condemnations of surveillance instead of proposing actionable legislation with penalties for abuses and compensation mechanisms for victims.

GUE_NGL strongly sanctions the issue's condemnation of member states' surveillance expansions, urging immediate Commission action to enforce Article 7 procedures against France's 2015 law and similar frameworks.  
GUE_NGL applauds the call for judicial redress mechanisms as aligning perfectly with their manifesto commitment to transnational accountability for intelligence abuses.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Clause 12 to mandate biannual parliamentary reviews of sunset clauses in national surveillance laws, ensuring stricter democratic oversight.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes that the issue effectively advances digital sovereignty through open-source infrastructure, directly countering U.S. surveillance-capitalist dominance.  
GUE_NGL absolutely endorses protections for whistleblowers like Snowden, demanding explicit safeguards for journalistic sources in the EU-US umbrella agreement.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over widespread electronic mass surveillance undermining EU citizens’ fundamental rights, particularly privacy and data protection, citing revelations of NSA activities, including espionage targeting French leaders and companies. It criticized Member States like France, the UK, and the Netherlands for expanding surveillance laws, urging compliance with EU law and the European Convention on Human Rights, and called on the Commission to assess France’s 2015 intelligence law. The resolution highlighted the invalidation of the EU-US Safe Harbour Agreement by the CJEU in October 2015, demanding immediate alternatives to ensure equivalent data protection and transparency on negotiations. It stressed the urgency of adopting the Data Protection Package by 2015, ensuring alignment with fundamental rights, and emphasized the need for judicial redress for EU citizens under the EU-US umbrella agreement, contingent on the US passing the Judicial Redress Act. The Parliament condemned inadequate Commission responses to prior recommendations, reserving the right to withhold budgetary resources until compliance. It advocated for stronger democratic oversight of intelligence services, including parliamentary scrutiny and sunset clauses for surveillance laws, and called for global standards on data protection to prevent a "surveillance arms race." The resolution urged IT independence through open-source software, enhanced encryption, and a European strategy for digital autonomy, while criticizing reliance on US surveillance-driven technologies. It also demanded protections for whistleblowers, journalists, and legal professionals, and pressed the Commission to address gaps in international data transfers and ensure remedies for surveillance victims by 2016.

title: Follow-up to the resolution of Parliament of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 11 February 20015 on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA
background: Revelations of EU member states' complicity in CIA secret detention and torture practices between 2001-2006, documented in the 2015 US Senate report and prior European investigations, prompted scrutiny of human rights violations on European territory. The Parliament will discuss member state accountability, counterterrorism compliance with international law, and obligations under human rights frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's unsubstantiated accusations against member states, citing lack of concrete evidence and reliance on NGO claims as inconsistent with due process principles.  
EPP opposes interference in ongoing national judicial investigations, asserting it violates subsidiarity and judicial independence enshrined in EU treaties.  
The proposal completely rejects with EPP's stance on national security by demanding excessive declassification through a Commission White Paper, creating unacceptable vulnerabilities.  
EPP highlights the issue's failure to address practical challenges in information gathering, noting the inefficacy of past parliamentary inquiries to produce actionable results.  
The text's politicized narrative risks damaging transatlantic counterterrorism cooperation vital to EU security interests, contradicting EPP's prioritization of strategic partnerships.

GREEN_EFA entirely upholds the issue’s demand for criminal investigations into CIA black sites, perfectly aligning with their unyielding commitment to accountability for human rights violations.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the condemnation of state secrecy abuses, emphasizing that Italy’s obstruction in the Nasr and Ghali case exemplifies systemic impunity requiring urgent redress.  
GREEN_EFA entirely upholds the call to resettle Guantánamo detainees, reflecting their decades-long advocacy for victims of extraordinary rendition and unlawful detention.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the demand for a Commission White Paper, viewing this as essential to prevent national security pretexts from undermining democratic scrutiny.  
GREEN_EFA entirely upholds the issue’s systemic critique, affirming that transparency in counterterrorism operations is non-negotiable for upholding EU values.

ECR rejects the issue's infringement on member states' national security sovereignty, asserting counterterrorism as a core state responsibility under EU treaties.  
ECR opposes demands for EU-level criminal investigations into CIA black sites, deeming them beyond Parliament's legal authority under Article 4(2) TEU.  
ECR firmly condemns with the issue's failure to address terrorist threats to "our civilization," creating an imbalance between human rights and security imperatives.  
ECR criticizes the proposal's disregard for member states' sovereign discretion in classifying documents related to intelligence operations.  
ECR objects to prioritizing judicial scrutiny over counterterrorism efficacy, warning against paralyzing security frameworks through excessive transparency demands.

GUE/NGL strongly promotes the issue’s demands for transparent criminal investigations into CIA black sites in Lithuania, Poland, Romania, and Italy, aligning perfectly with GUE/NGL’s longstanding commitment to accountability for human rights violations and opposition to state secrecy obstructing justice.  
GUE/NGL applauds the emphasis on closing Guantánamo Bay and ensuring fair trials for detainees, which matches their 2016 manifesto priorities to end indefinite detention and uphold international law.  
GUE/NGL urges enhanced pressure on the US to prohibit torture unequivocally, noting that the issue’s criticism of unmet closure pledges under Obama should be expanded to include concrete timelines for current obligations.  
GUE/NGL proposes extending scrutiny to all EU Member States implicated in rendition complicity, such as Ireland’s Shannon Airport use, to ensure no state evades accountability—a minor enhancement to strengthen the issue’s scope.  
GUE/NGL emphasizes the systemic failures highlighted in the issue, particularly the need for democratic accountability to prevent future abuses, which effectively advances GUE/NGL’s priority of rooting out institutionalized impunity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over the CIA’s rendition, secret detention, and torture programs between 2001 and 2006, implicating EU Member States in human rights violations, including unlawful detention, torture, enforced disappearances, and complicity through the use of European airspace and territory. It condemned the lack of accountability by Member States and the US, citing insufficient investigations, excessive reliance on state secrecy, and failure to prosecute perpetrators, despite evidence from the US Senate’s 2014 report and European Court of Human Rights rulings (e.g., Nasr and Ghali v Italy in 2016, which confirmed Italy’s use of state secrecy to shield officials involved in Abu Omar’s abduction). The resolution urged Lithuania, Poland, Romania, and Italy to conduct transparent criminal investigations into CIA black sites, declassify documents, and prosecute those responsible, while criticizing obstacles like undue document classification and slow judicial processes. It reiterated calls for the US to close Guantánamo Bay, ensure fair trials for detainees, prohibit torture, and cooperate with EU investigations, noting President Obama’s unmet 2010 closure pledge and his 2016 plan to Congress. The Parliament emphasized transatlantic cooperation rooted in human rights, rule of law, and accountability, urging the EU and US to align counterterrorism efforts with international law, and demanded a Commission White Paper clarifying limits on invoking national security to block scrutiny. It also pressed Member States to assist in resettling cleared Guantánamo detainees and ensure compliance with ECHR judgments, including Poland’s obligation to seek US assurances against the death penalty and Macedonia’s establishment of an independent investigatory body. The resolution highlighted systemic failures to address torture, enforced disappearances, and arbitrary detention, stressing the need for transparency and democratic accountability to uphold EU values.

title: Full application of the provisions of the Schengen acquis in Bulgaria and Romania: REPORT on the full application of the provisions of the Schengen acquis in Bulgaria and Romania: abolition of checks at internal land, sea and air borders
background: Bulgaria and Romania, EU members since 2007, completed Schengen evaluation requirements by 2011 but faced prolonged Council delays in abolishing internal border controls under the Schengen acquis. The Parliament will discuss their full integration into the Schengen Area.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the immediate abolition of all internal border checks for Bulgaria and Romania, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to Schengen as a cornerstone of European integration.  
EPP proposes enhancing anti-corruption monitoring mechanisms across all Schengen states to ensure uniform evaluation criteria, addressing concerns raised without delaying accession.  
EPP approves the issue’s condemnation of the Council’s unjustified two-step approach, which starkly contradicts prior enlargement precedents and EU legal coherence.  
EPP highlights the issue’s economic rationale, stressing that prolonged border controls disproportionately harm cross-border trade and EU market unity, a priority in EPP’s 2024 agenda.  
EPP urges the Council to adopt a single legal act abolishing checks unconditionally, as mandated by the 2005 Accession Treaty, to restore institutional credibility and deter populist narratives.

ALDE strongly advocates the immediate abolition of all internal border checks for Bulgaria and Romania, aligning with their full compliance with Schengen criteria since 2011 as confirmed by EU evaluations.  
ALDE emphasizes that the Council’s prolonged delay contradicts the principle of equal application of EU law and undermines trust in European institutions, urging a single legal act to fully integrate both countries into Schengen.  
ALDE highlights the critical need for Bulgaria and Romania to gain full access to all Schengen information systems, noting that partial access creates security vulnerabilities at the EU’s external borders.  
ALDE proposes accelerating technical preparations for land border integration alongside the immediate removal of air and sea checks to ensure seamless implementation.  
ALDE commends the issue’s focus on economic costs of border controls, which disproportionately affect cross-border trade and transport efficiency in Southeastern Europe.

SD completely promotes the immediate adoption of a single legal act abolishing all internal border checks for Bulgaria and Romania, as this perfectly aligns with their 2011 fulfillment of Schengen criteria and SD's commitment to non-discriminatory European integration.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's rejection of phased accession, condemning the Council's seven-year delay as a politically motivated violation of the 2005 Accession Treaty's unified integration principle.  
SD completely promotes the economic urgency arguments, emphasizing that maintaining border controls imposes €2 billion annual operational costs while undermining cross-border trade and transport efficiency.  
SD strongly upholds the issue's linkage between Schengen integrity and EU credibility, noting that exclusion of compliant states like Bulgaria and Romania dangerously fuels anti-EU populism.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands for equal treatment of Balkan members, stressing that Romania and Bulgaria's exemplary management of EU external borders warrants full Schengen benefits without additional conditions.

ECR slightly sanctions the call for immediate Schengen integration but demands binding timelines to prevent indefinite political delays by member states.  
ECR requests revisions to Article 5 regarding border management, mandating joint patrols with objecting states like Austria to address migration concerns raised during evaluations.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of asymmetric implementation, failing to penalize existing members who maintain internal checks without justification.  
ECR firmly rejects the two-step approach as inconsistent with treaty obligations, but notes the issue's silence on compensation mechanisms for transport sector losses violates subsidiarity principles.  
This framework conflicts with ECR's insistence on national accountability by not requiring periodic audits of Frontex operations in Bulgaria and Romania as precondition for full accession.

resolution: The European Parliament raised that Bulgaria and Romania fulfilled all Schengen acquis requirements by 2011, including border management, data protection, and police cooperation, as confirmed by the Schengen Evaluation Working Group and the Council. Despite this, the Council has delayed full accession for seven years, deviating from the 2005 Act of Accession, which mandates a single legal act for abolishing internal border checks. Parliament criticized the Council’s proposed two-step approach (abolishing sea/air borders first, land borders later) as unjustified and inconsistent with prior Schengen enlargements, warning it risks fragmenting the EU, undermining trust, and fueling populism. It highlighted the economic costs of maintaining internal border controls, including estimated one-off costs of €0.05–20 billion and annual operational costs of €2 billion, disproportionately affecting cross-border trade, transport, and tourism. While welcoming partial integration steps, such as 2017 Visa Information System access and 2018 Schengen Information System proposals, Parliament stressed that Bulgaria and Romania currently bear Schengen obligations without full benefits. It urged the Council to adopt a single decision abolishing all internal border checks immediately, emphasizing that no additional criteria beyond the 2005 Act should apply, and called for Croatia’s swift Schengen accession upon meeting evaluation criteria. Parliament reiterated that prolonged delays erode EU credibility, exacerbate legislative gaps, and weaken the internal market, stressing Schengen’s role as a cornerstone of European integration.

title: Fundamental rights aspects in Roma integration in the EU: fighting anti-Gypsyism: REPORT on fundamental rights aspects in Roma integration in the EU: fighting anti-Gypsyism
background: Persistent structural discrimination against Roma communities across EU member states, including socioeconomic exclusion, educational segregation, housing inequalities, and healthcare disparities, compounded by historical persecution and rising anti-Gypsyism, has driven systemic human rights concerns. The Parliament will discuss EU policy frameworks for combating institutional racism and advancing Roma integration through fundamental rights protections.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the issue’s condemnation of assimilation policies, advocating instead for full integration into national identities to prevent societal fragmentation.  
ENF opposes the issue’s perceived attack on nationalist MEPs’ freedom of expression, framing it as ideological exploitation of Roma issues.  
ENF entirely disputes with the issue’s anti-paternalism stance, insisting state-led assimilation is the only path to respect Roma dignity and social cohesion.  
ENF criticizes the issue’s neglect of communitarianism risks, arguing assimilation aligns with ENF’s principle of unified national communities over minority separatism.  
ENF overlooks systemic discrimination claims, prioritizing citizenship-based assimilation over structural equality measures deemed divisive to EU societies.

SD strongly approves the issue’s holistic rights-based approach to Roma integration, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to dismantling systemic discrimination and upholding the EU’s fundamental rights charter.  
SD approves the emphasis on combating anti-Gypsyism through education and employment initiatives, which advances SD’s priority to eradicate stereotypes and ensure equal access to opportunities for Roma communities.  
SD endorses the call for desegregation in housing and education, urging stricter enforcement of anti-eviction policies and accelerated integration of Roma children into mainstream schools to address systemic neglect.  
SD applauds the gender-sensitive strategies addressing intersectional discrimination against Roma women, proposing to enhance the truth commission’s mandate by explicitly including documentation of forced sterilizations and healthcare neglect.  
SD strongly approves allocating 20% of ESF resources to marginalized groups, emphasizing robust monitoring mechanisms to ensure funds directly combat poverty and exclusion in line with SD’s social justice agenda.

ECR rejects the issue's allegations of systemic discrimination in housing and healthcare as unsubstantiated, asserting that claims of forced sterilizations and segregated facilities constitute ideological smears inconsistent with factual governance.  
ECR opposes centralized EU integration mandates, emphasizing that Roma inclusion falls strictly under national competence and subsidiarity principles, as demonstrated by Denmark's challenges with abusive mobility framework exploitation.  
ECR fundamentally condemns with the portrayal of Roma as passive victims, arguing the issue overlooks successful Slovak models where Christian NGOs empowered community-led responsibility and socioeconomic upliftment.  
ECR disputes the validity of EU-funded desegregation quotas, condemning the 20% ESF allocation proposal as disregarding documented misappropriation risks and ineffective past spending on Roma-specific programs.  
ECR challenges the issue's historical reconciliation mechanisms, dismissing truth commissions as revisionist tools that distort property rights frameworks and national historical narratives.

GUE/NGL strongly accepts the issue's recognition of anti-Gypsyism as systemic racism, aligning perfectly with their commitment to dismantling structural inequalities in housing, education, and healthcare.  
GUE/NGL approves the call to end segregated schooling and forced evictions, emphasizing the need to reallocate EU funds to combat poverty affecting 80% of Roma communities.  
GUE/NGL proposes broadening statelessness provisions to explicitly address non-citizen populations in Latvia and Estonia, enhancing the issue’s inclusivity.  
GUE/NGL applauds the demand for truth commissions and Roma Holocaust recognition, mirroring their longstanding advocacy for historical justice and reparations.  
GUE/NGL urges strengthening gender-sensitive strategies to explicitly criminalize forced sterilizations and systemic healthcare neglect against Roma women.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about pervasive anti-Gypsyism and systemic discrimination against Roma communities across the EU, emphasizing structural inequalities in access to housing, healthcare, education, employment, and justice. It highlighted alarming statistics, including 80% of Roma facing poverty risks, 47% of Roma children missing early education, 63% of young Roma not in employment or training (compared to a 12% EU average), and 41% experiencing discrimination in key areas. The resolution condemned forced evictions, segregation in substandard housing (e.g., 10,000 Roma evicted in France in 2016), segregated healthcare and education (e.g., 30.9% of Roma pupils in Czech special schools), and statelessness affecting thousands. It urged Member States to establish national and EU-level truth and reconciliation commissions to address historical persecution, enforce existing anti-discrimination laws (e.g., Racial Equality Directive), and allocate at least 20% of ESF resources to marginalized groups. The Parliament called for desegregation measures, improved Roma participation in policymaking, gender-sensitive strategies addressing intersectional discrimination against Roma women (e.g., forced sterilizations and healthcare neglect), and mandatory anti-bias training for public officials. It stressed the need for robust monitoring of EU funds, enhanced hate crime reporting, and a revised post-2020 EU Roma strategy prioritizing anti-Gypsyism. Additionally, it demanded restitution for Holocaust survivors, recognition of 2 August as Roma Holocaust Memorial Day, and urgent action to end statelessness, ensure birth registration, and provide equal access to utilities and justice.

title: Fundamental rights implications of big data: REPORT on fundamental rights implications of big data: privacy, data protection, non-discrimination, security and law-enforcement
background: Rapid growth of big data technologies, widespread collection of personal data through connected devices and online platforms, and increasing use of advanced analytics by public and private entities have raised concerns under EU legal frameworks. The Parliament will discuss fundamental rights implications regarding privacy, data protection, non-discrimination, and security in evolving data-driven decision-making.

stances.stance:
